Linear programming and the intersection of free subgroups in free products of groups

S. V. Ivanov Department of Mathematics
University of Illinois
Urbana
IL 61801
U.S.A. ivanov@illinois.edu
Abstract.

We study the intersection of finitely generated factor-free subgroups of free products of groups by utilizing the method of linear programming. For example, we prove that if H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of the free product G1*G2 of two finite groups G1, G2, then the Walter Neumann coefficient σ⁢(H1) of H1 is rational and can be computed. This coefficient σ⁢(H1) is the minimal positive real number such that, for every finitely generated factor-free subgroup H2 of G1*G2, it is true that r¯⁢(H1,H2)≤σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2), where r¯⁢(H)=max⁡(r⁢(H)-1,0) is reduced rank of H, r⁢(H) is rank of H, and r¯⁢(H1,H2) is reduced rank of a generalized intersection of H1,H2.

Key words and phrases:
Free products of groups, free and factor-free subgroups, rank of intersection of factor-free subgroups, linear programming.
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary 20E06, 20E07, 20F65, 90C90.
Supported in part by the NSF under grant DMS 09-01782.

1. Introduction

Let Gα, α∈I, be some nontrivial groups and let ℱ=∏α∈I*Gα denote the free product of these groups. According to the classic Kurosh subgroup theorem [20], [21], every subgroup H of ℱ is a free product F⁢(H)*∏*tα,γ⁢Hα,γ⁢tα,γ-1, where Hα,γ is a subgroup of Gα, tα,γ∈ℱ, and F⁢(H) is a free subgroup of ℱ such that, for every s∈ℱ and γ∈I, it is true that F⁢(H)∩s⁢Gγ⁢s-1={1}. We say that H is a factor-free subgroup of ℱ if H=F⁢(H) in the above form of H, i.e., for every s∈ℱ and γ∈I, we have H∩s⁢Gγ⁢s-1={1}. Let r⁢(F) denote the rank of a (finitely generated) free group F. Since a factor-free subgroup H of ℱ is free, the reduced rank r¯⁢(H):=max⁡(r⁢(H)-1,0) of H, where r⁢(H) is the rank of H, is well defined.

Let q*=q*(Gα,α∈I) denote the minimum of orders >2 of finite subgroups of groups Gα, α∈I, and let q*:=∞ if there are no such subgroups. It is clear that either q* is an odd prime or q*∈{4,∞}. If q*=∞, define q*q*-2:=1. Dicks and the author [6] proved that if H1, H2 are finitely generated factor-free subgroups of ℱ, then

r¯⁢(H1∩H2)≤2⁢q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2). (1.1)

Dicks and the author [6] conjectured that if groups Gα, α∈I, contain no involutions, then the coefficient 2 could be left out and

r¯⁢(H1∩H2)≤q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2). (1.2)

This conjecture can be regarded as a far reaching generalization of the Hanna Neumann conjecture [23] on rank of the intersection of subgroups in free groups. Recall that the Hanna Neumann conjecture [23] claims that if H1, H2 are finitely generated subgroups of a free group, then r¯⁢(H1∩H2)≤r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2). For more discussion, partial results and proofs of this conjecture the reader is referred to [4], [5], [8], [18], [22], [24], [26], [27].

The conjecture (1.2) is established by Dicks and the author [7] in the case when ℱ is the free product of two groups of order 3 in which case q*=3 and (1.2) turns into

r¯⁢(H1∩H2)≤q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2)=3⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2).

Another special case in which the conjecture (1.2) is known to be true is the case when ℱ is the free product of infinite cyclic groups, i.e., ℱ is a free group, as follows from Friedman’s [8] and Mineyev’s [22] proofs of the Hanna Neumann conjecture, see also Dicks’s proof [5]. In this case q*=∞ and the inequality (1.2) turns into

r¯⁢(H1∩H2)≤r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2). (1.3)

More generally, the inequality (1.3) also holds in the case when ℱ is the free product of right orderable groups as follows from results of Antolín, Martino, and Schwabrow [1], see also [18]. We mention that it follows from results of [6] that the conjectured inequality (1.2) is sharp and may not be improved.

In an attempt to improve on the bound (1.1) in a special case, Dicks and the author [7] showed that

r¯⁢(H1∩H2)≤(2-(4+2⁢3)⁢p(2⁢p-3+3)2)⋅pp-2⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2) (1.4)

for finitely generated factor-free subgroups H1, H2 of the free product Cp*Cp of two cyclic groups of prime order p>2.

Note that for p=3 the inequality (1.4) yields the conjectured inequality (1.2). However, for prime p≥5, the problem whether the inequality (1.2) holds for the free product of two cyclic groups of order p remains open and seems to be the most basic and appealing case of the conjecture (1.2) for groups with torsion. In this connection, we remark that the ideas of articles [1], [5], [8], [22], do not look to be applicable to the case of free products with torsion and shed no light on the conjecture (1.2) for free products of groups with torsion, especially, for free products of finite groups.

In this article, however, we will not attempt to prove or improve on any upper bounds. Instead, we will look at generalized intersections of finitely generated factor-free subgroups in free products of groups from a disparate standpoint and prove results of quite different flavor by utilizing the method of linear programming.

First we recall a stronger version of the conjecture (1.2) that generalizes the strengthened Hanna Neumann conjecture which was put forward by Walter Neumann [24] for subgroups of free groups. Let H1, H2 be finitely generated factor-free subgroups of an arbitrary free product ℱ=∏α∈I*Gα of groups Gα, α∈I, let the number q*q*-2 be defined for ℱ as above, and let S⁢(H1,H2) denote a set of representatives of those double cosets H1⁢t⁢H2 of ℱ, t∈ℱ, that have the property H1∩t⁢H2⁢t-1≠{1}. Then the strengthened version of the conjecture (1.2) claims that

r¯⁢(H1,H2):=∑s∈S⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H1∩s⁢H2⁢s-1)≤q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2), (1.5)

where r¯⁢(H1,H2) is reduced rank of the generalized intersection of H1 and H2 consisting of subgroups H1∩s⁢H2⁢s-1, s∈S⁢(H1,H2).

Let 𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ) denote the set of all finitely generated noncyclic factor-free subgroups of the free product ℱ. Pick a subgroup H1∈𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ). We will say that a real number σ⁢(H1)>0 is the Walter Neumann coefficient for H1, or, briefly, the WN-coefficient for H1, if, for every H2∈𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ), we have

r¯⁢(H1,H2)≤σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2) (1.6)

and σ⁢(H1) is minimal with this property. Clearly,

σ⁢(H1)=sup⁡{r¯⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2)}

over all subgroups H2∈𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ).

For every integer d≥3, we also define the number

σd⁢(H1):=sup⁡{r¯⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2)} (1.7)

over all subgroups H2∈𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ,d), where 𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ,d) is a subset of 𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ) consisting of those subgroups whose irreducible core graphs have all of its vertices of degree at most d, see Sect. 2 for definitions. This number σd⁢(H1) is called the WNd-coefficient for H1. Since 𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ,d)⊆𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ,d+1), it follows from the definitions that σd⁢(H1)≤σd+1⁢(H1)≤σ⁢(H1) and limd→∞⁡σd⁢(H1)=σ⁢(H1).

For example, it folows from results of [6, 7] mentioned above that if ℱ=Cp*Cp is the free product of two cyclic groups of prime order p>2 and H1∈𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ), then

pp-2≤σd⁢(H1)≤σ⁢(H1)≤(2-(4+2⁢3)⁢p(2⁢p-3+3)2)⋅pp-2.

The main technical result of this article is the following.

Theorem 1.1.

Suppose that F=G1*G2 is the free product of two nontrivial groups G1,G2 and H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of F. Then the following claims are true.

(a) For every integer d≥3, there exists a linear programming problem (LP-problem)

𝒫⁢(H1,d)=max⁡{c⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)∣A⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)≤b⁢(d)} (1.8)

with integer coefficients whose solution is equal to -σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1).

(b) There is a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H2* of F, H2*=H2*⁢(H1), which corresponds to a vertex solution of the dual problem

𝒫*⁢(H1,d)=min⁡{b⁢(d)⊤⁢y⁢(d)∣A⁢(d)⊤⁢y⁢(d)=c⁢(d)⊤,y⁢(d)≥0}

of the primal LP-problem (1.8) of part (a) such that r¯⁢(H1,H2*)=σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2*). In particular, the WNd-coefficient σd⁢(H1) of H1 is rational. Furthermore, if Ψ⁢(H1), Ψ⁢(H2*) denote irreducible core graphs representing subgroups H1,H2*, resp., and |E⁢Ψ| is the number of oriented edges in a graph Ψ, then

|E⁢Ψ⁢(H2*)|<224⁢|E⁢Ψ⁢(H1)|+1+log2⁡log2⁡(2⁢d).

(c) There exists a linear semi-infinite programming problem (LSIP-problem) P⁢(H1)=sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} with finitely many variables in x and with countably many constraints in the system A⁢x≤b whose dual problem

𝒫*⁢(H1)=inf⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0}

has a solution equal to -σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1).

(d) Let the word problem for both groups G1,G2 be solvable and let an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H1) of H1 be given. Then the LP-problem (1.8) of part (a) can be effectively written down and the WNd-coefficient σd⁢(H1) for H1 can be computed. In addition, an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H2*) of the subgroup H2* of part (b) can be effectively constructed.

(e) Let both G1,G2 be finite, let d:=max⁡(|G1|,|G2|)≥3, and let an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H1) of H1 be given. Then the LP-problem (1.8) of part (a) coincides with the LSIP-problem P⁢(H1) of part (c) and the WN-coefficient σ⁢(H1) for H1 is rational and computable.

It is worthwhile to mention that the correspondence H2→y⁢(H2) between subgroups H2∈𝒦𝖿𝖿⁢(ℱ,d), with a special property (Bd), see Sect. 3, and vectors y⁢(H2) of the feasible polyhedron {y⁢(d)∣A⁢(d)⊤⁢y⁢(d)=c⁢(d)⊤,y⁢(d)≥0} of the dual problem 𝒫*⁢(H1,d), that is mentioned in part (b) of Theorem 1.1, plays an important role in proofs and is reminiscent of the correspondence between (almost) normal surfaces in 3-dimensional manifolds and their (resp. almost) normal vectors in the Haken theory of normal surfaces and its generalizations, see [10, 11, 12, 16, 19]. In particular, the idea of a vertex solution works equally well both in the context of almost normal surfaces [16], see also [11, 19], and in the context of factor-free subgroups, providing in either situation both the connectedness of the underlying object represented by a vertex solution and an upper bound on size of the underlying object.

Relying on the linear programming approach of Theorem 1.1, in the following Theorem 1.2, we look at the computational complexity of the problem to calculate the WN-coefficient σ⁢(H1) for a factor-free subgroup H1 of the free product of two finite groups.

Theorem 1.2.

Suppose that F=G1*G2 is the free product of two nontrivial finite groups G1,G2 and H1 is a subgroup of F given by a finite generating set S of words over the alphabet A=G1∪G2. Then the following are true.

(a) In deterministic polynomial time of size of S, one can determine whether H1 is factor-free and noncyclic and, if so, one can construct an irreducible graph Ψo⁢(H1) of H1.

(b) If H1 is factor-free and noncylcic, then, in deterministic exponential time of size of S, one can write down and solve an LP-problem P=max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} whose solution is equal to -σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1). In particular, the W⁢N-coefficient σ⁢(H1) of H1 is computable in deterministic exponential time of size of S.

(c) If H1 is factor-free and noncylcic, then, in deterministic double exponential time of size of S, one can construct an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H2*) of H2*, where H2* is a finitely generated factor-free subgroup F such that r¯⁢(H1,H2*)=σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2*). In addition, if |E⁢Ψ| denotes the number of oriented edges of a graph Ψ, Ψ⁢(H1) is an irreducible core graph of H1, and d:=max⁡(|G1|,|G2|), then |E⁢Ψ⁢(H2*)|<224⁢|E⁢Ψ⁢(H1)|+1+log2⁡log2⁡(2⁢d).

The situation with free products of more than two factors is more difficult to study and we will make additional efforts to obtain the following.

Theorem 1.3.

Suppose that F=∏α∈I*Gα is the free product of nontrivial groups Gα, α∈I, and H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of F. Then there are two disjoint finite subsets I1,I2 of I such that if ^⁢G1:=∏α∈I1*Gα, ^⁢G2:=∏α∈I2*Gα, and ^⁢F:=^⁢G1*^⁢G2, then there exists a finitely generated factor-free subgroup ^⁢H1 of ^⁢F with the following properties.

(a) r¯⁢(^⁢H1)=r¯⁢(H1), σd⁢(^⁢H1)≥σd⁢(H1) for every d≥3, and σ⁢(^⁢H1)≥σ⁢(H1). In particular, if the conjecture (1.5) fails for H1 then the conjecture (1.5) also fails for ^⁢H1.

(b) If the word problem for all groups Gα, α∈I1∪I2, is solvable and a finite irreducible graph of H1 is given, then the LP-problem P⁢(^⁢H1,d) for ^⁢H1 of part (a) of Theorems 1.1 can be effectively written down and the WNd-coefficient σd⁢(^⁢H1) for ^⁢H1 can be computed.

(c) Let groups Gα, where α∈I1∪I2, be finite, let H1 be effectively given either by a finite irreducible graph or by a finite generating set, and let

d′:=max⁡{|I1∪I2|,max⁡{|Gα|:α∈I1∪I2}}.

Then σd′⁢(^⁢H1)≥σ⁢(H1) and there is an algorithm that decides whether the conjecture (1.5) holds for H1.

We remark that proofs of Theorems 1.2–1.3 provide a practical deterministic algorithm (with exponential running time, though) to compute the WN-coefficient σ⁢(H1) for a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H1 of the free product of two finite groups and to determine whether a certain finitely generated factor-free subgroup of a free product of finite groups satisfies the conjecture (1.5). It seems to be of interest to implement this algorithm and experiment with it.

The article is structured as follows. In Sect. 2, we define basic notions and recall geometric ideas that are used to study finitely generated factor-free subgroups and their intersections in a free product ℱ. In particular, we define a finite labeled graph Ψ⁢(H) associated with such a subgroup H of ℱ. In Sect. 3, we consider the free product ℱ=G1*G2 of two nontrivial groups G1,G2 and introduce certain linear inequalities associated with the groups G1,G2 and with a graph Ψ⁢(H1) of H1, where H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of ℱ. Informally, these inequalities are used for construction of cores of potential fiber product graphs Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2), where H2 is another finitely generated factor-free subgroup of ℱ, and subsequent translation to linear programming. More formally, these inequalities enable us to define an LP-problem max⁡{c⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)∣A⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)≤b⁢(d)}, corresponding to Ψ⁢(H1) and to an integer d≥3, and to define an LSIP-problem sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}, corresponding to Ψ⁢(H1). We also consider and make use of the dual problems of the primal problems max⁡{c⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)∣A⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)≤b⁢(d)}, sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}. Basic results and terminology of linear programming are recalled in Sect. 4. These LP-, LSIP-problems and their dual problems are investigated in Sects. 3–4. In Sect. 5, we look at the case of free products of more than two groups and prove a few more technical lemmas. Proofs of Theorems 1.1–1.3 are given in Sect. 6.

2. Preliminaries

Let Gα, α∈I, be nontrivial groups, let ℱ=∏α∈I*Gα be their free product, and let H be a finitely generated factor-free subgroup of ℱ, H≠{1}. Consider the alphabet 𝒜=∪α∈IGα, where Gα∩Gα′={1} if α≠α′.

Analogously to the graph-theoretic approach of articles [6, 7, 13, 14, 15, 17, 18], we first define a labeled 𝒜-graph Ψ⁢(H) which geometrically represents H in a manner similar to the way Stallings graphs represent subgroups of a free group, see [26].

If Γ is a graph, V⁢Γ denotes the vertex set of Γ and E⁢Γ denotes the set of oriented edges of Γ. For e∈E⁢Γ let e-, e+ denote the initial, terminal, resp., vertices of e and let e-1 be the edge with the opposite (to e) orientation, where e-1≠e for every e∈E⁢Γ, (e-1)-=e+, (e-1)+=e-. A path p=e1⁢…⁢ek in Γ is a sequence of edges e1,…,ek such that (ei)+=(ei+1)-, i=1,…,k-1. Define p-:=(e1)-, p+:=(ek)+, and |p|:=k, where |p| is the length of p. We allow the possibility that p={p-}={p+} and |p|=0. A path p is closed if p-=p+. A path p is called reduced if p contains no subpaths of the form e⁢e-1, e∈E⁢Γ. A closed path p=e1⁢…⁢ek is cyclically reduced if |p|>0 and both p and the cyclic permutation e2⁢…⁢ek⁢e1 of p are reduced paths. The core of a graph Γ, denoted core⁢(Γ), is the minimal subgraph of Γ that contains every edge e which can be included into a cyclically reduced path in Γ.

Let Ψ be a graph whose vertex set V⁢Ψ consists of two disjoint nonempty parts VP⁢Ψ,VS⁢Ψ, so V⁢Ψ=VP⁢Ψ∪VS⁢Ψ. Vertices in VP⁢Ψ are called primary and vertices in VS⁢Ψ are called secondary. Every edge e∈E⁢Ψ connects primary and secondary vertices, hence Ψ is a bipartite graph. Ψ is called a labeled A-graph, or briefly 𝒜-graph, if Ψ is equipped with functions

φ:E⁢Ψ→𝒜,θ:VS⁢Ψ→I,

called labeling, such that, for every edge e∈E⁢Ψ, it is true that φ⁢(e)∈𝒜=∪α∈IGα, φ⁢(e-1)=φ⁢(e)-1, and, if e+∈VS⁢Ψ, then φ⁢(e)∈Gα for α=θ⁢(e+). If e+∈VS⁢Ψ, define θ⁢(e):=θ⁢(e+), θ⁢(e-1):=θ⁢(e+) and call θ⁢(e+), θ⁢(e) the type of a vertex e+∈VS⁢Ψ and of an edge e∈E⁢Ψ. Thus, for every e∈E⁢Ψ, we have defined an element φ⁢(e)∈𝒜, called the label of e, and an element θ⁢(e)∈I, termed the type of e.

The reader familiar with van Kampen diagrams over a free product of groups, as defined in [21], will recognize that our labeling function φ:E⁢Ψ→𝒜 is defined in the way analogous to labeling functions on van Kampen diagrams over free products of groups. Recall that van Kampen diagrams are planar 2-complexes whereas graphs are 1-complexes, however, apart from this, the ideas of cancelations and edge folding work equally well for both diagrams and graphs.

An 𝒜-graph Ψ is called irreducible if properties (P1)–(P3) hold true:

  1. (P1)

    If e,f∈E⁢Ψ, e-=f-∈VP⁢Ψ, and e+≠f+, then θ⁢(e)≠θ⁢(f).

  2. (P2)

    If e,f∈E⁢Ψ, e≠f, and e+=f+∈VS⁢Ψ, then φ⁢(e)≠φ⁢(f) in Gθ⁢(e).

  3. (P3)

    Ψ has no multiple edges, degΨ⁢v>0 for every v∈V⁢Ψ, and there is at most one vertex of degree 1 in Ψ which, if exists, is primary.

Suppose Ψ is a connected finite irreducible 𝒜-graph and a primary vertex o∈VP⁢Ψ is distinguished so that degΨ⁡o=1 if Ψ happens to have a vertex of degree 1. Then o is called the base vertex of Ψ=Ψo.

As usual, elements of the free product ℱ=∏α∈I*Gα are regarded as words over the alphabet 𝒜=∪α∈IGα, where Gα∩Gα′={1} if α≠α′. A syllable of a word W over 𝒜 is a maximal nonempty subword of W all of whose letters belong to the same factor Gα. The syllable length ∥W∥ of W is the number of syllables of W, while the length |W| of W is the number of all letters in W. For example, if a1,a2∈Gα, then |a1⁢1⁢a2|=3, ∥a1⁢1⁢a2∥=1, and |1|=∥1∥=1.

A nonempty word W over 𝒜 is called reduced if every syllable of W consists of a single letter. Clearly, |W|=∥W∥ if W is reduced. Note that an arbitrary nontrivial element of the free product ℱ can be uniquely written as a reduced word. A word W is called cyclically reduced if W2 is reduced. We write U⁢=0⁢W if words U, W are equal as elements of ℱ. The literal (or letter-by-letter) equality of words U, W is denoted U≡W.

If p=e1⁢…⁢ek is a path in an 𝒜-graph Ψ and e1,…,ek are edges of Ψ, then the label φ⁢(p) of p is the word φ⁢(p):=φ⁢(e1)⁢…⁢φ⁢(ek).

The significance of irreducible 𝒜-graphs for geometric interpretation of factor-free subgroups H of ℱ is given in the following lemma.

Lemma 2.1.

Suppose H is a finitely generated factor-free subgroup of the free product F=∏α∈I*Gα, H≠{1}. Then there exists a finite connected irreducible A-graph Ψ=Ψo⁢(H), with a base vertex o, such that a reduced word W over the alphabet A belongs to H if and only if there is a reduced path p in Ψo⁢(H) such that p-=p+=o, φ⁢(p)⁢=0⁢W in F, and |p|=2⁢|W|.

In addition, assume that all factors Gα, α∈I, are finite and V1,…,Vk are words over A. Then there is an algorithm which, in time polynomial of |V1|+…+|Vk|, decides whether the subgroup HV=⟨V1,…,Vk⟩, generated by V1,…,Vk, is factor-free and, if so, constructs an irreducible A-graph Ψo⁢(HV) for HV.

Proof.

The proof is based on Stallings’s folding techniques and is somewhat analogous to the proof of van Kampen lemma for diagrams over free products of groups, see [21] (in fact, it is simpler because foldings need not preserve the property of being planar for diagrams).

Let HV=⟨V1,…,Vk⟩ be a subgroup of ℱ, generated by some words V1,…,Vk over 𝒜. Without loss of generality we can assume that V1,…,Vk are reduced words. Consider a graph ~⁢Ψ which consists of k closed paths p1,…,pk such that they have a single common vertex o=(pi)-, and |pi|=2⁢|Vi|, i=1,…,k. We distinguish o as the base vertex of ~⁢Ψ and call o primary, the vertices adjacent to o are called secondary vertices and so on. Denote V≡ai,1⁢…⁢ai,ℓi, where ai,j∈𝒜 are letters, i=1,…,k, and let pi=ei,1⁢fi,1⁢…⁢ei,ℓi⁢fi,ℓi, where ei,j,fi,j are edges of the path pi. The labeling functions φ,θ on the path pi are defined so that if ai,j∈Gα⁢(i,j), then

θ⁢(ei,j):=α⁢(i,j),θ⁢(fi,j):=α⁢(i,j),φ⁢(ei,j):=ai,j⁢bi,j-1,φ⁢(fi,j):=bi,j,

where bi,j is an element of the group Gα⁢(i,j).

Clearly, φ⁢(pi)⁢=0⁢Vi in ℱ for all i=1,…,k.

It is also clear that ~⁢Ψ=~⁢Ψo is a finite connected 𝒜-graph with the base vertex o that has the following property.

  • (Q)

    A word W∈ℱ belongs to H if and only if there is a path p in ~⁢Ψo such that p-=p+=o and φ⁢(p)⁢=0⁢W.

However, ~⁢Ψo need not be irreducible and we will do foldings of edges in ~⁢Ψo which preserve property (Q) and which are aimed to achieve properties (P1)–(P2).

Assume that property (P1) fails for edges e,f with e-=f-∈VP⁢~⁢Ψo so that e+≠f+ and θ⁢(e)=θ⁢(f). Let us redefine the labels of all edges e′ with e+′=e+ so that φ⁢(e′)⁢φ⁢(e)-1 does not change and φ⁢(e)=φ⁢(f) in Gθ⁢(e). This can be done by multiplication of φ-labels on the right by φ⁢(e)-1⁢φ⁢(f). Since φ⁢(e)=φ⁢(f) and θ⁢(e)=θ⁢(f), we may now identify the edges e, f and vertices e+, f+. Observe that this folding preserves property (Q) ((P2) might fail) and decreases the total edge number |E⁢~⁢Ψo|. This operation changes the labels of edges and can be done in time polynomial in |V1|+…+|Vk| if all factors Gα, α∈I, are finite. Note that if Gα were not finite, then there would be a problem with increasing space needed to store φ-labels of edges and subsequent computations with larger labels.

If property (P2) fails for edges e,f and φ⁢(e)=φ⁢(f) in Gθ⁢(e), then we identify the edges e,f. Note property (Q) still holds ((P1) might fail) and the number |E⁢~⁢Ψo| decreases.

Suppose property (P3) fails and there are two distinct edges e,f in ~⁢Ψo such that e-=f- and e+=f+∈VS⁢~⁢Ψo. If φ⁢(e)≠φ⁢(f) in Gθ⁢(e), then a conjugate of φ⁢(e)⁢φ⁢(f)-1∈Gθ⁢(e) is in HV, hence we conclude that HV is not factor-free. So we may assume that φ⁢(e)=φ⁢(f) in Gθ⁢(e). Then we identify the edges e,f, thus preserving property (Q) and decreasing the number |E⁢~⁢Ψo|. If property (P3) fails so that there is a vertex v of degree 1, different from o, then we delete v along with the incident edge. Clearly, property (Q) still holds and the number |E⁢~⁢Ψo| decreases.

Thus, by induction on |E⁢~⁢Ψo| in polynomially many (relative to ∑i=1k|Vi|) steps as described above, we either establish that the subgroup HV is not factor-free or construct an irreducible 𝒜-graph Ψo with property (Q).

It follows from the definitions and from property (Q) of the graph Ψo that HV is factor-free (see also Lemma 2.2). Other stated properties of Ψo are straightforward.

Finally, we observe that if all factors Gα, α∈I, are finite, then the space required to store the φ-label of an edge of intermediate graphs is constant and multiplication (or inversion) of φ-labels would require time bounded by a constant. Therefore, the above procedure implies the existence of a polynomial algorithm for finding out whether a subgroup HV=⟨V1,…,Vk⟩ of ℱ is factor-free and for construction of a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Ψo for HV. ∎

The following lemma further elaborates on the correspondence between finitely generated factor-free subgroups of the free product ℱ and finite irreducible 𝒜-graphs.

Lemma 2.2.

Let Ψo be a finite connected irreducible A-graph with the base vertex o and let H=H⁢(Ψo) be a subgroup of the free product F that consists of all words φ⁢(p), where p is a path in Ψo such that p-=p+=o. Then H is a factor-free subgroup of F and r¯⁢(H)=-χ⁢(Ψo), where χ⁢(Ψo)=|V⁢Ψo|-12⁢|E⁢Ψo| is the Euler characteristic of Ψo.

Proof.

This follows from the facts that the fundamental group π1⁢(Ψo,o) of Ψo at o is free of rank -χ⁢(Ψo)+1 and that the homomorphism π1⁢(Ψo,o)→ℱ, given by p→φ⁢(p), where p is a path with p-=p+=o, has the trivial kernel in view of properties (P1)–(P2). ∎

Suppose H is a nontrivial finitely generated factor-free subgroup of a free product ℱ=∏α∈I*Gα, and Ψo=Ψo⁢(H) is a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph for H as in Lemma 2.1. We say that Ψo⁢(H) is an irreducible graph of H.

Let Ψ⁢(H):=core⁡(Ψo⁢(H)) denote the core of an irreducible graph Ψo⁢(H) of H. Clearly, Ψ⁢(H) has no vertices of degree ≤1 and Ψ⁢(H) is also an irreducible 𝒜-graph. We say that Ψ⁢(H) is an irreducible core graph of H.

It is easy to see that an irreducible graph Ψo⁢(H) of H can be obtained back from an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H) of H by attaching a suitable path p to Ψ⁢(H) so that p starts at a primary vertex o, ends in p+∈VP⁢Ψ⁢(H), and then by doing foldings of edges as in the proof of Lemma 2.1, see Fig. 2.1.

\usetikzlibrary

arrows {tikzpicture}[scale=.92] \nodeat (-2,0) Ψo⁢(H); \nodeat (0,0.8) Ψ⁢(H)=; \nodeat (0,0.3) core⁢Ψo⁢(H); \draw(0,-0.7)[fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(0,.5) ellipse (1.02 and 1.2); \drawplot[smooth, tension=.8] coordinates (0,-0.7)(-0.5,-1.5) (-1,-1) (-1.5,-1.5) (-2,-1.2) (-2.5,-1.5) (-2.8,-1.5); \draw[-latex] (-1.269,-1.26) – (-1.21,-1.16); \draw(-2.8,-1.5)[fill = black]circle (0.05); \nodeat (-1.5,-1.1) p; \nodeat (-2.8,-1.1) o; \nodeat (.0,-2.2) Fig. 2.1;

Now suppose H1, H2 are nontrivial finitely generated factor-free subgroups of ℱ. Consider a set S⁢(H1,H2) of representatives of those double cosets H1⁢t⁢H2 of ℱ, t∈ℱ, that have the property H1∩t⁢H2⁢t-1≠{1}. For every s∈S⁢(H1,H2), define the subgroup Ks:=H1∩s⁢H2⁢s-1. Similarly to articles [13, 14, 15, 17, 18] and analogously to the case of free groups, see [4, 24], we now construct a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Ψ⁢(H1,H2), also denoted core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2)), whose connected components are irreducible core graphs Ψ⁢(Ks), s∈S⁢(H1,H2).

First we define an 𝒜-graph Ψo′⁢(H1,H2). The set of primary vertices of Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) is VP⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2):=VP⁢Ψo1⁢(H1)×VP⁢Ψo2⁢(H2). Let

τi:VP⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2)→VP⁢Ψoi⁢(Hi)

denote the projection map, τi⁢((v1,v2))=vi, i=1,2.

The set of secondary vertices VS⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) of Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) consists of equivalence classes [u]α, where u∈VP⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2), α∈I, with respect to the minimal equivalence relation generated by the following relation ∼𝛼 on the set VP⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2). Define v⁢∼𝛼⁢w if and only if there are edges ei,fi∈E⁢Ψoi⁢(Hi) such that

(ei)-=τi⁢(v),(fi)-=τi⁢(w),(ei)+=(fi)+

for each i=1,2, the edges ei,fi have type α, and φ⁢(e1)⁢φ⁢(f1)-1=φ⁢(e2)⁢φ⁢(f2)-1 in Gα. It is easy to see that the relation ∼𝛼 is symmetric and transitive on pairs and triples of distinct elements (but it could lack the reflexive property).

The edges in Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) are defined so that u∈VP⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) and [v]α∈VS⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) are connected by an edge if and only if u∈[v]α.

The type θ⁢([v]α) of a vertex [v]α∈VS⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) is α and if e∈E⁢Ψo′⁢(H1,H2), e-=u, e+=[v]α, then φ⁢(e):=φ⁢(e1), where e1∈E⁢Ψo1⁢(H1) is an edge of type α with (e1)-=τ1⁢(u), when such an e1 exists, and φ⁢(e1):=gα, where gα∈Gα, gα≠1, otherwise.

It follows from the definitions and properties (P1)–(P2) of Ψoi⁢(Hi), i=1,2, that Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) is an 𝒜-graph with properties (P1)–(P2). Hence, taking the core of Ψo′⁢(H1,H2), we obtain a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph which we denote by Ψ⁢(H1,H2) or by core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2)).

It is not difficult to see that, when taking the connected component Ψo′⁢(H1,H2,o) of Ψo′⁢(H1,H2) that contains the vertex o=(o1,o2) and inductively removing from Ψo′⁢(H1,H2,o) vertices of degree 1 different from o, we obtain an irreducible 𝒜-graph Ψo⁢(H1∩H2) with the base vertex o that corresponds to the intersection H1∩H2 as in Lemma 2.1.

It follows from the definitions and property (P1) for Ψ⁢(Hi), i=1,2, that, for every edge e∈E⁢Ψ⁢(H1,H2) with e-∈VP⁢Ψ⁢(H1,H2), there are unique edges ei∈E⁢Ψ⁢(Hi) such that τi⁢(e-)=(ei)-, i=1,2. Hence, by setting τi⁢(e)=ei, τi⁢(e+)=(ei)+, i=1,2, we extend τi to the graph map

τi:Ψ⁢(H1,H2)→Ψ⁢(Hi),i=1,2. (2.1)

It follows from the definitions that τi is locally injective and τi preserves syllables of the word φ⁢(p) for every path p with primary vertices p-,p+.

Lemma 2.3.

Suppose H1, H2 are finitely generated factor-free subgroups of the free product F and S⁢(H1,H2)≠∅. Then the connected components of the graph Ψ⁢(H1,H2) are core graphs Ψ⁢(H1∩s⁢H2⁢s-1) of subgroups H1∩s⁢H2⁢s-1, s∈S⁢(H1,H2). In particular, r¯⁢(H1,H2):=∑s∈S⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H1∩s⁢H2⁢s-1)=-χ⁢(Ψ⁢(H1,H2)).

Proof.

This is straightforward, details can be found in [18]. ∎

3. The system of linear inequalities 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]

In this Section, we let ℱ2=G1*G2 be the free product of two nontrivial groups G1,G2, let 𝒜=G1∪G2 be the alphabet, G1∩G2={1}, and let Y1 be a finite connected irreducible 𝒜-graph such that core⁡(Y1)=Y1 and r¯⁢(Y1):=-χ⁢(Y1)>0. In particular, Y1 has no vertices of degree 1 and Y1 contains a vertex of degree >2.

Let S2⁢(Gα), where α=1,2, denote the set of all finite subsets of Gα of cardinality ≥2 and let S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) denote the set of all nonempty subsets of VP⁢Y1. For every T∈S2⁢(Gα), consider a function

ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1).

We also consider a relation ∼ΩT on the set of all pairs (a,u), where a∈T and u∈ΩT⁢(a), defined as follows. Two pairs (a,u), (b,v) are related by ∼ΩT, written (a,u)∼ΩT(b,v), if and only if the following holds. Either (a,u)=(b,v) or, otherwise, there exist edges e,f∈E⁢Y1 with the properties that e-=u, f-=v, the secondary vertex e+=f+ has type α, and φ⁢(e)⁢φ⁢(f)-1=a⁢b-1 in Gα, see an example depicted in Fig. 3.1. It is easy to see that the relation ∼ΩT is an equivalence one.

{tikzpicture}

[scale=.64] \draw(-2,2) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(-2,3) node (v1) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(-2,4) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(-2.3,3) ellipse (1.1 and 1.8);

\draw

(0,6) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(1,6.) node (v5) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(2,6) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(1,6.3) ellipse (1.8 and 1.1);

\draw

(4,2) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(4,3) node (v3) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(4,4) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(4.3,3) ellipse (1.1 and 1.8);

(0,0) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(1,0) node (v4) [fill = black]circle (0.05); \draw(2,0) [fill = black]circle (0.055); \draw(1,-.3) ellipse (1.8 and 1.1);
