(1,3) node (v2) circle (0.08); \draw[-latex] (-.6,3) – (-.4,3); \draw[-latex] (2.6,3) – (2.4,3); \draw[-latex] (1,1.4) – (1,1.6); \draw[-latex] (1,4.6) – (1,4.4); \draw(v1) edge (v2); \draw(v2) edge (v3); \draw(v2) edge (v4); \draw(v5) edge (v2); \nodeat (-2.5,2) u2; \nodeat (-2.5,3) u5; \nodeat (-2.5,4) u8; \nodeat (0,6.5) u1; \nodeat (1,6.5) u2; \nodeat (2,6.5) u3; \nodeat (4.5,4) u3; \nodeat (4.5,3) u4; \nodeat (4.5,2) u5; \nodeat (2,-0.5) u1; \nodeat (1,-0.5) u6; \nodeat (0,-0.5) u7; \nodeat (1.5,4.5) e1; \nodeat (2.5,2.5) e2; \nodeat (0.5,1.5) e3; \nodeat (-0.5,3.5) e4; \nodeat (-9,6) T={g1,g2,g3,g4}⊆Gα, ; \nodeat (-9,5) ΩT⁢(g1)={u1,u2,u3}, ; \nodeat (-9,4) ΩT⁢(g2)={u3,u4,u5}, ; \nodeat (-9,3) ΩT⁢(g3)={u1,u6,u7}, ; \nodeat (-9,2) ΩT⁢(g4)={u2,u5,u8}, ; \nodeat (-8.4,1) ΩT⁢(gi)⊆VP⁢Y1,φ⁢(ei)=gi,i=1,2,3,4, ; \nodeat (-8,0) (g1,u2)∼ΩT(g2,u4)∼ΩT(g3,u6)∼ΩT(g4,u5). ;

\node

at (4.2,6.4) ΩT⁢(g1); \nodeat (4.5,0.5) ΩT⁢(g2) ; \nodeat (3.7,-1.24) ΩT⁢(g3); \nodeat (-2.3,5.5) ΩT⁢(g4); \nodeat (-3,-2.2) Fig. 3.1;

Let [(a,u)]∼ΩT denote the equivalence class of (a,u) and let |[(a,u)]∼ΩT| denote the cardinality of [(a,u)]∼ΩT. It follows from the definitions that

1≤|[(a,u)]∼ΩT|≤|T|. (3.1)

We will say that the equivalence class [(a,u)]∼ΩT is associated with a secondary vertex w∈VS⁢Y1 of type α if w=e+, where e∈E⁢Y1 and e-=u. It is easy to see that the definition of w is independent of u in [(a,u)]∼ΩT.

A function ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), T∈S2⁢(Gα), is called α-admissible if

|[(a,u)]∼ΩT|≥2

for every equivalence class [(a,u)]∼ΩT, where a∈T, u∈ΩT⁢(a). The set of all α-admissible functions is denoted Ω⁢(Y1,α), α=1,2.

Let ΩT∈Ω⁢(Y1,α) be an α-admissible function, T∈S2⁢(Gα), and let

Nα⁢(ΩT):=∑(|[(a,u)]∼ΩT|-2) (3.2)

denote the sum of cardinalities minus two over all equivalence classes [(a,u)]∼ΩT, where a∈T and u∈ΩT⁢(a), of the equivalence relation ∼ΩT.

Let r be the number of all equivalence classes [(a,u)]∼ΩT of the equivalence relation ∼ΩT, where a∈T and u∈ΩT⁢(a). If r≥|VP⁢Y1|, then it follows from (3.2) and definitions that

Nα⁢(ΩT)=∑(|[(a,u)]∼ΩT|-2)≤|T|⋅|VP⁢Y1|-2⁢r≤(|T|-2)⁢|VP⁢Y1|.

On the other hand, if r≤|VP⁢Y1|, then it follows from (3.1) and (3.2) that

Nα⁢(ΩT)=∑(|[(a,u)]∼ΩT|-2)≤(|T|-2)⁢r≤(|T|-2)⁢|VP⁢Y1|.

Thus, in any case, it is shown that

Nα⁢(ΩT)≤(|T|-2)⁢|VP⁢Y1|. (3.3)

For every A∈S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), we consider a variable xA. We also introduce a special variable xs. Now we will define a system of linear inequalities in these variables. For every α-admissible function ΩT, where T∈S2⁢(Gα), α=1,2, denote T={b1,…,bk} and set Ai:=ΩT⁢(bi), i=1,…,k. If α=1, then the inequality, corresponding to the α-admissible function ΩT, is defined as follows

-xA1-…-xAk-(k-2)⁢xs≤-N1⁢(ΩT). (3.4)

If α=2, then the inequality corresponding to the α-admissible function ΩT is written in the following form

xA1+…+xAk-(k-2)⁢xs≤-N2⁢(ΩT). (3.5)

Let d≥3 be an integer and 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1] denote the system of linear inequalities (3.4)–(3.5) over all α-admissible functions ΩT, ΩT∈Ω⁢(Y1,α), α=1,2. Since the set S2⁢(Gα) is in general infinite (unless Gα is finite) and the set S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) is finite (because Y1 is finite), it follows that 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1] is an infinite system of linear inequalities with integer coefficients over a finite set of variables xA,A∈S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), xs.

Let

𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] (3.6)

denote the subsystem of the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1] whose linear inequalities (3.4)–(3.5) are defined for all α-admissible functions ΩT, ΩT∈Ω⁢(Y1,α), α=1,2, such that |T|≤d. If q is an inequality of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] then the coefficient of xs in the left-hand side of q is an integer -k+2, where 2≤k=|T|≤d, and the right-hand side of q is an integer -Nα⁢(ΩT), where 0≤Nα⁢(ΩT)≤(d-2)⁢|VP⁢Y1|, as follows from inequality (3.3). Also, the number of subsets A⊆VP⁢Y1 that index variables ±xA in the left-hand side of q is finite and the total number of occurrences of such variables ±xA in q is k=|T|≤d. Therefore, 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] is a finite system of linear inequalities and 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]=∪d=3∞𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1].

Let Y2 be a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph. Consider the following property of Y2.

  1. (B)

    The map τ2:core⁡(Y1×Y2)→Y2 is surjective, core⁡(Y2)=Y2, and r¯⁢(Y2):=-χ⁢(Y2)>0.

If Γ is a finite graph, let deg⁡Γ denote the maximum of degrees of vertices of Γ. We will also use one more property.

  1. (Bd)

    Y2 has property (B) and deg⁡Y2≤d, where d≥3 is an integer.

Suppose Y2 is a graph with property (B). For every secondary vertex u∈VS⁢Y2 of type α, consider all edges e1,…,eℓ, where deg⁡u=ℓ, such that u=(e1)+=…=(eℓ)+ and denote vj=(ej)-, j=1,…,ℓ. Define Tu:={φ⁢(e1),…,φ⁢(eℓ)}. Clearly, Tu⊆S2⁢(Gα). Define the sets Aj:=τ1⁢τ2-1⁢(vj)⊆VP⁢Y1 for j=1,…,ℓ and consider the function

ΩTu:Tu→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1)

so that ΩTu⁢(φ⁢(ej))=Aj.

It is easy to check that ΩTu is α-admissible. Since every α-admissible function Ω∈Ω⁢(Y1,α) gives rise to an inequality (3.4) if α=1 or to an inequality (3.5) if α=2 and every secondary vertex u∈VS⁢Y2 of type α defines, as indicated above, an α-admissible function ΩTu, it follows that every u∈VS⁢Y2 is mapped to a certain inequality of the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1], denoted 𝗂𝗇𝗊S⁡(u). Thus we obtain a function

𝗂𝗇𝗊S:VS⁢Y2→𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]

defined from the set VS⁢Y2 of secondary vertices of a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Y2 with property (B) to the set of inequalities of 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1].

If q is an inequality of the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1], denoted q∈𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1], we let qL denote the left-hand side of q and let qR denote the integer in the right-hand side of q.

Lemma 3.1.

In the foregoing notation, if deg⁡u≤d for every u∈VS⁢Y2, then 𝗂𝗇𝗊S⁡(VS⁢Y2)⊆𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]. Furthermore,

∑u∈VS⁢Y2𝘪𝘯𝘲S(u)L=-2r¯(Y2)xs,𝑎𝑛𝑑∑u∈VS⁢Y2𝘪𝘯𝘲S(u)R=-2r¯(core(Y1×Y2)).
Proof.

The inclusion 𝗂𝗇𝗊S⁡(VS⁢Y2)⊆𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] is evident from the definitions.

Suppose v∈VP⁢Y2 and let e1, e2 be the edges such that (e1)-=(e2)-=v and φ⁢(eα)∈Gα, α=1,2. Clearly, uα:=(eα)+, α=1,2, is a secondary vertex of Y2. Denote Av:=τ1⁢τ2-1⁢(v). It follows from the definitions that Av∈S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) and that the variables -xAv, xAv occur in 𝗂𝗇𝗊S(u1)L, 𝗂𝗇𝗊S(u2)L, resp., and will cancel out in the sum 𝗂𝗇𝗊S(u1)L+𝗂𝗇𝗊S(u2)L. It is easy to see that all occurrences of variables ±xA, A∈S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), in the formal sum

∑u∈VS⁢Y2𝗂𝗇𝗊S(u)L,

before any cancelations are made, can be paired down by using primary vertices of Y2 as indicated above. Since every secondary vertex u of Y2 contributes -(deg⁡u-2) to the coefficient of xs in ∑u∈VS⁢Y2𝗂𝗇𝗊S(u)L and

∑u∈VS⁢Y2(deg⁡u-2)=2⁢r¯⁢(Y2), (3.7)

the first equality of Lemma 3.1 becomes evident. The second equality follows from the analogous to (3.7) formula

∑u∈VS⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))(deg⁡u-2)=2⁢r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2)),

and from the definition (3.2) of numbers Nα⁢(Ω⁢(u)), u∈VS⁢Y2. ∎

Let A={a1,…,an} be a finite set. A combination with repetitions B of A, which we denote B=[[b1,…,bm]], is a finite unordered collection of multiple copies of elements of A. Hence bi∈A and bi=bj is possible for i≠j.

Observe that a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Y2 with property (Bd) can be used to construct a combination with repetitions, denoted 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢Y2) (note that, in general, 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢Y2)≠𝗂𝗇𝗊S⁡(VS⁢Y2) as 𝗂𝗇𝗊S⁡(VS⁢Y2)⊆𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]), of the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1], whose elements are individual inequalities of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] so that every inequality q=𝗂𝗇𝗊S⁡(u) of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] occurs in 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢Y2) as many times as the number of preimages of q in VS⁢Y2 under 𝗂𝗇𝗊S. It follows from Lemma 3.1 that if 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢Y2)=[[q1,…,qm]], then

∑q∈𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢Y2)qL:=∑j=1mqjL=-2⁢r¯⁢(Y2)⁢xs.

In the opposite direction, we will prove the following.

Lemma 3.2.

Suppose Q is a nonempty combination with repetitions of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] and

∑q∈QqL=-C⁢xs, (3.8)

where C>0 is an integer. Then there exists a finite irreducible A-graph YQ such that YQ has property (Bd) and 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢YQ)=Q. In particular,

∑q∈𝘪𝘯𝘲⁡(VS⁢YQ)qL=-2⁢r¯⁢(YQ)⁢xs 𝑎𝑛𝑑 ∑q∈𝘪𝘯𝘲⁡(VS⁢YQ)qR=-2⁢r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×YQ)). (3.9)
Proof.

We will construct an 𝒜-graph YQ whose set VS⁢YQ of secondary vertices is in bijective correspondence uj→qj, j=1,…,m, with elements of Q=[[q1,…,qm]] so that vertices of type α in VS⁢YQ correspond to inequalities of type α in Q, see (3.4)–(3.5). To fix notation, we let the inequality qj be defined by means of an αj-admissible function

Ωj:Tj→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1),

where Tj∈S2⁢(Gαj), Tj={b1,j,…,bkj,j}, 2≤kj≤d, bℓ,j∈Gαj.

Consider a secondary vertex uj of type αj and kj edges e1,j,…,ekj,j whose terminal vertex is uj and whose labels are φ⁢(e1,j)=b1,j,…, φ⁢(ekj,j)=bkj,j. This is a local structure of the graph YQ around its secondary vertices. Now we will identify in pairs initial vertices of edges e1,j,…,ekj,j, j=1,…,m, which will form the set of primary vertices VP⁢YQ of the graph YQ. In the notation introduced above, it follows from the definitions (3.4)–(3.5) that a typical term ±xA of qjL has the form (-1)αj⁢xA, where A=Ωj⁢(bℓ,j) for some ℓ=1,…,kj.

It follows from equality (3.8) that there is an involution map ι on the set of ±xA terms of the formal sum ∑j=1mqjL that takes every term ±xA of qjL to a term ∓xA of qj′L, j≠j′, and ι2=id. Therefore, if

(-1)αj⁢xΩj⁢(bℓ,j) and (-1)αj′⁢xΩj′⁢(bℓ′,j′)

are two terms of the formal sum ∑j=1mqjL which are ι-images of each other, then {αj,αj′}={1,2} and Ωj⁢(bℓ,j)=Ωj′⁢(bℓ′,j′). We identify the initial vertices of the edges eℓ,j, eℓ′,j′ so that (eℓ,j)-=(eℓ′,j′)- becomes a primary vertex of YQ. Doing this identification for initial vertices of the pairs of edges, corresponding as above to all pairs of canceling symbols ±xA, ∓xA in ∑j=1mqjL, results in an 𝒜-graph YQ. It is not difficult to see from the definitions and from α-admissibility of functions Ω1,…,Ωm that YQ is a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph with core⁡(YQ)=YQ, that 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢YQ)=Q, and that the map

τQ:core⁡(Y1×YQ)→YQ

is surjective. Note that the map τQ is the analogue of τ2, see (2.1). Hence, YQ has property (B). Clearly, deg⁡u≤d for every u∈VS⁢YQ, whence YQ also has property (Bd). The equalities (3.9) follow from Lemma 3.1. ∎

We summarize Lemmas 3.1–3.2 in the following.

Lemma 3.3.

The function 𝗂𝗇𝗊:Y2→𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢Y2)=Q from the set of finite irreducible A-graphs Y2 with property (Bd) to the set of combinations Q with repetitions of the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] with the property ∑q∈QqL=-C⁢xs, where C>0 is an integer, is surjective. In addition, if 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(VS⁢Y2)=Q then

∑q∈QqL=-2⁢r¯⁢(Y2)⁢xs 𝑎𝑛𝑑 ∑q∈QqR=-2⁢r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2)).
Proof.

This is straightforward from Lemmas 3.1–3.2 and their proofs. ∎

4. Utilizing Linear and Linear Semi-infinite Programming

First we briefly review relevant results from the theory of linear programming (LP) over the field ℚ of rational numbers. Following the notation of Schrijver’s monograph [25], let A∈ℚm×n be an m×n-matrix, let b∈ℚn×1=ℚn be a column vector, let c∈ℚ1×n be a row vector, c=(c1,…,cn), and let x be a column vector consisting of variables x1,…,xn, so x=(x1,…,xn)⊤, where M⊤ means the transpose of a matrix M. The inequality x≥0 means that xi≥0 for every i.

A typical LP-problem asks about the maximal value of the objective linear functional

c⁢x=c1⁢x1+…+cn⁢xn

over all x∈ℚn subject to a finite system of linear inequalities A⁢x≤b. This value (and often the LP-problem itself) is denoted

max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}.

We write max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=-∞ if the set {c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is empty. We write max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=+∞ if the set {c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is unbounded from above and say that max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is finite if the set {c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is nonempty and bounded from above. The notation and terminology for an LP-problem

min⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=-max⁡{-c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}

is analogous with -∞ and +∞ interchanged.

If max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is an LP-problem as defined above, then the problem

min⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0},

where y=(y1,…,ym)⊤, is called the dual problem of the primal LP-problem max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}.

The (weak) duality theorem of linear programming can be stated as follows, see [25, Sect. 7.4].

Theorem A.

Let max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} be an LP-problem and let min⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0} be its dual LP-problem. Then for every x∈Qn such that A⁢x≤b and every y∈Qm such that A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0, one has c⁢x≤y⊤⁢A⁢x≤b⊤⁢y and

max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=min⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0} (4.1)

provided both polyhedra {x∣A⁢x≤b} and {y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0} are not empty. In addition, the minimum, whenever it is finite, is attained at a vector ^⁢y which is a vertex of the polyhedron {y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0}.

Since the system of inequalities 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1], as defined in Sect. 3, is infinite in general, we also recall basic terminology and results regarding duality in linear semi-infinite programming (LSIP), see [2], [3], [9]. Consider a generalized LP-problem max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} that has countably many linear inequalities in the system A⁢x≤b while the number of variables in x is still finite. Hence, in this setting, A is a matrix with countably many rows and n columns, or A∈ℚ∞×n is an ∞×n-matrix, b∈ℚ∞×1=ℚ∞, or b is an infinite column vector, c∈ℚ1×n is a row vector, and x=(x1,…,xn)⊤.

A typical LSIP-problem over ℚ asks about the supremum of the objective linear functional c⁢x over all x∈ℚn subject to A⁢x≤b. This number and the problem itself is denoted sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}. As above, we write sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=-∞ if the set {c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is empty, sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=+∞ if the set {c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is not bounded from above and say that sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is finite if the set {c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is nonempty and bounded from above. The notation and terminology for an LSIP-problem inf⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=-sup⁡{-c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is analogous with -∞ and +∞ interchanged. Let Ai denote the submatrix of A of size i×n whose first i rows are those of A and bi is the the starting subcolumn of b of length i. Then max⁡{c⁢x∣Ai⁢x≤bi} is an LP-problem which is called the i-approximate of the LSIP-problem sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}.

Let Mi=max⁡{c⁢x∣Ai⁢x≤bi} denote the optimal value of the i-approximate LP-problem max⁡{c⁢x∣Ai⁢x≤bi} and M is the number sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}. Clearly, for every i, Mi≥Mi+1≥M. Note that in general limi→∞⁡Mi≠M, see [2, 3].

Similarly to [2], [3], [9], we say that if sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is an LSIP-problem as above, then the problem

inf⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0},

where y=(y1,y2,…)⊤ is an infinite vector whose set of nonzero components is finite, is called the dual problem of sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}.

For later reference, we state an analogue of Theorem A for linear semi-infinite programming which, in fact, is an easy corollary of Theorem A.

Theorem B.

Suppose that sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is an LSIP-problem whose set {c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is nonempty and bounded from above and whose dual problem is inf⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0}. Then

sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}≤inf⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0} (4.2)

and the equality holds if and only if sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} is equal to limi→∞⁡Mi, where Mi:=max⁡{c⁢x∣Ai⁢x≤bi} is the optimal solution of the i-approximate LP-problem max⁡{c⁢x∣Ai⁢x≤bi} of the primal LSIP-problem sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}.

In the situation when the inequality (4.2) is strict, the difference inf⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0}-sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}>0 is called the duality gap of the LSIP-problem sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}.

We will also need a corollary of the complementary slackness and Carathéodory theorem, see [25, Corollary 7.11].

Theorem C.

If both optima in (4.1) are finite, then the minimum is attained at a vector y^, y^≥0, whose positive components correspond to linear independent columns of A⊤, i.e., rows of A.

We now consider the problem of maximizing the objective linear functional c⁢x:=-xs over all rational vectors x, x∈ℚn′, for a suitable n′, subject to the system of linear inequalities 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1], as an LP-problem max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}. Note that, in this context, m′=m𝗂𝗇𝗊 and n′=n𝗂𝗇𝗊, where m𝗂𝗇𝗊 is the number of inequalities in 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1] and n𝗂𝗇𝗊 is the number of all variables xj,A,xs in 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1].

We now consider the problem of maximizing the objective linear functional

c⁢x:=-xs

over all rational vectors x, x∈ℚn for a suitable n, subject to the system of linear inequalities 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1] introduced in Sect. 3, as an LSIP-problem sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}.

We also consider a subsequence of id-approximate LP-problems max⁡{c⁢x∣Aid⁢x≤bid} of the LSIP-problem sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} whose systems Aid⁢x≤bid of inequalities are finite subsystems 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] of 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1], where d=3,4,…, as defined in (3.6).

It is straightforward to verify that the dual problem inf⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0} of this LSIP-problem sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} can be equivalently stated as follows

∑j=1∞yj⁢qjR→inf subject to y≥0,∑j=1∞yj⁢qjL=-xs, (4.3)

where almost all yj, j=1,2,…, are 0’s. We rewrite (4.3) in the form

inf⁡{∑j=1∞yj⁢qjR∣∑j=1∞yj⁢qjL=-xs,y≥0}. (4.4)

Analogously, the dual problem of the id-approximate LP-problem max⁡{c⁢x∣Aid⁢x≤bid} can be stated in the form

∑j=1idyj⁢qjR→min subject to y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs

which we will write as

min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs,y≥0}. (4.5)

In Lemma 3.3, we established the existence of a surjective function

𝗂𝗇𝗊:Y2→𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(Y2)

from the set of finite irreducible 𝒜-graphs Y2 with property (Bd) to a certain set of combinations with repetitions of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]. Now we will relate these combinations with repetitions of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] to solutions of the dual LP-problem (4.5).

Consider a combination with repetitions Q of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] that has the property

∑q∈QqL=-C⁢(Q)⁢xs, (4.6)

where C⁢(Q)>0 is an integer. As before, let all inequalities of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] be q1,…,qid, let ℓj⁢(Q) denote the number of times that qj occurs in Q, and let δj be the coefficient of xs in qj. Then it follows from the definitions and (4.6) that

∑q∈QqL=∑j=1idδj⁢ℓj⁢(Q)⁢xs=-C⁢(Q)⁢xs. (4.7)

Consider the map

𝗌𝗈𝗅d:Q→yQ=(yQ,1,…,yQ,id)⊤, (4.8)

where yQ,j:=ℓj⁢(Q)C⁢(Q) for j=1,…,id. It follows from the definitions that yQ is a rational vector, yQ≥0 and, by (4.7), yQ satisfies the condition

∑j=1idyQ,j⁢qjL=-xs.

Hence, yQ is a vector in the polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} of the dual LP-problem (4.5).

Conversely, let ^⁢y=(^⁢y1,…,^⁢yid)⊤ be a vector of the feasible polyhedron

{y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}

of the dual LP-problem (4.5). Let C>0 be a common multiple of positive denominators of the rational numbers ^⁢y1,…,^⁢yid. Consider a combination with repetitions Q=Q⁢(^⁢y) of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] such that every qj of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] occurs in Q  C⁢^⁢yj=ℓj many times. Then it follows from the definitions that

∑q∈QqL=∑j=1idℓj⁢qjL=∑j=1idC⁢^⁢yj⁢qjL=C⁢∑j=1id^⁢yj⁢qjL=-C⁢xs.

Now we can see that the vector yQ=𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(Q⁢(^⁢y)), defined by (4.8) for Q, is equal to ^⁢y, i.e., 𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(Q⁢(^⁢y))=^⁢y.

We now summarize our findings.

Lemma 4.1.

The map 𝗌𝗈𝗅d:Q→yQ defined by (4.8) is a surjective function from the set of combinations Q with repetitions of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] that satisfy an equation ∑q∈QqL=-C⁢xs, where C>0 is an integer, to the set of vectors of the rational polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} of the dual LP-problem (4.5). Furthermore, the composition of the maps 𝗂𝗇𝗊 and 𝗌𝗈𝗅d,  𝗌𝗈𝗅d∘𝗂𝗇𝗊:Y2→^⁢y=^⁢y⁢(Y2), provides a surjective function from the set of finite irreducible A-graphs with property (Bd) to the set of points of the rational polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} of the dual LP-problem (4.5). Under this map, the value of the objective function ∑j=1id^⁢yj⁢qjR of the dual LP-problem (4.5) at ^⁢y=^⁢y⁢(Y2) satisfies

∑j=1id^⁢yj⁢qjR=-r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))r¯⁢(Y2). (4.9)
Proof.

As was observed above, 𝗌𝗈𝗅d is surjective, hence, by Lemma 3.3, the composition 𝗌𝗈𝗅d∘𝗂𝗇𝗊 is also surjective. Consider a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Y2 with property (Bd) and define Q:=𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(Y2), ^⁢y:=𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(Q). It follows from Lemma 3.3 that

∑q∈QqL=-2⁢r¯⁢(Y2)⁢xs  and ∑q∈QqR=-2⁢r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2)). (4.10)

In view of the definition (4.7) and Lemma 3.3, we have C⁢(Q)=2⁢r¯⁢(Y2). Hence, it follows from the definition (4.8) and equalities (4.10) that

∑j=1id^⁢yj⁢qjR=(∑q∈QqR)⁢C⁢(Q)-1=-r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))r¯⁢(Y2),

as required. ∎

We will say that a real number σ⁢(Y1)≥0 is the Walter Neumann coefficient, or briefly WN-coefficient, for Y1 if

r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))≤σ⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y2)

for every finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Y2 with property (B) and σ⁢(Y1) is minimal with this property.

We also consider the WNd-coefficient σd⁢(Y1), where d≥3 is an integer, for Y1 defined so that

r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))≤σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y2)

for every finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Y2 with property (Bd) and σd⁢(Y1) is minimal with this property. It is clear from the definitions that σd⁢(Y1)≤σd+1⁢(Y1)≤σ⁢(Y1) for every d=3,4,…, that σ⁢(Y1)=sup⁡r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))r¯⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y2) over all finite irreducible 𝒜-graphs Y2 with property (B) and that σd⁢(Y1)=sup⁡r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2′))r¯⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y2′) over all finite irreducible 𝒜-graphs Y2′ with property (Bd).

Lemma 4.2.

Suppose d≥max⁡{deg⁡u∣u∈VS⁢Y1}=deg⁡Y1 is an integer. Then both optima max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]} and min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} are finite and satisfy the following inequalities and equalities

-2⁢q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(Y1)≤sup⁡{-xs∣𝘚𝘓𝘐⁡[Y1]}≤max⁡{-xs∣𝘚𝘓𝘐d⁡[Y1]}==min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}=-σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1). (4.11)

Furthermore, the minimum is attained at a vector ^⁢y⁢(d), ^⁢y⁢(d)≥0, which is a vertex of the polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} and

inf⁡{∑j=1∞yj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1∞yj⁢qjL=-xs}=-σ⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)≤min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}=-σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1). (4.12)

In particular, σd⁢(Y1)≤σ⁢(Y1)≤2⁢q*q*-2.

Proof.

Setting Y2:=Y1, we get a solution ^⁢y=𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(Y2)) to the system y≥0,  ∑j=1∞yj⁢qjL=-xs. Hence, both sets

{y∣y≥0,∑j=1∞yj⁢qjL=-xs},{y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}

are not empty.

To see that the sets {x∣𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]}, {x∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]} are not empty either, we will show that ^⁢x, whose components are ^⁢xA=0 for every A⊆VP⁢Y1 and ^⁢xs=2⁢q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(Y1), is a solution both to 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] and to 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]. To do this, we will check that every inequality of 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1] is satisfied with these values of variables, that is,

-(k-2)⋅2⁢q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(Y1)≤-Nα⁢(ΩT) (4.13)

for every α-admissible function ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), where T∈S2⁢(Gα), |T|=k. Let T={a1,…,ak}, k≥2, ai∈Gα, and ΩT⁢(ai)=Ai, i=1,…,k. Consider a secondary vertex u of Y1, suppose deg⁡u=ℓ and let e1,…,eℓ be all edges of Y1 with u=(e1)+=…=(eℓ)+. Denote B:={φ⁢(e1),…,φ⁢(eℓ)}. It is not difficult to see from the definition (3.2) of Nα⁢(ΩT) that the contribution to the sum Nα⁢(ΩT) made by those equivalence classes that are associated with the vertex u∈VS⁢Y1 does not exceed ∑g∈Gαmax⁡(|T∩B⁢g|-2,0). Hence, it follows from the definition of q*q*-2 and from results of Dicks and the author [6, Corollary 3.5] that

∑g∈Gαmax⁡(|T∩B⁢g|-2,0)≤q*q*-2⁢(|T|-2)⁢(|B|-2)=q*q*-2⁢(k-2)⁢(ℓ-2). (4.14)

Therefore, summing up inequalities (4.14) over all vertices u∈VS⁢Y1, we arrive at

Nα⁢(Ω)≤q*q*-2⁢(k-2)⋅2⁢r¯α⁢(Y1)≤q*q*-2⁢(k-2)⋅2⁢r¯⁢(Y1),

where 2⁢r¯α⁢(Y1) is the sum ∑(deg⁡u-2) over all u∈VS⁢Y2 of type α. This proves (4.13) and also shows that

-xs≥-2⁢q*q*-2⁢r¯⁢(Y1).

Thus, according to Theorem A, the maximum and minimum in (4.11) are finite and equal. Inequalities in (4.11) are shown. Recall that, by Theorem A, the minimum min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} is attained at a vertex ^⁢y⁢(d) of the polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}.

By Lemma 4.1, for every irreducible 𝒜-graph Y2 with property (Bd), the ratio -r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))r¯⁢(Y2) is ∑j=1id^⁢yj⁢qjR, where ^⁢y=𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(Y2)), and the map

𝗌𝗈𝗅d∘𝗂𝗇𝗊:Y2→^⁢y

covers the feasible polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}. Hence, the supremum

σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1):=supY2⁡r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))r¯⁢(Y2)=-infY2⁡(-r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))r¯⁢(Y2))

over all graphs Y2 with property (Bd) is equal to

σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1) =-inf⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}
=-min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}
=-∑j=1id^⁢yj⁢(d)⁢qjR=-max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]},

where ^⁢y⁢(d) is a vertex of the polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} at which the minimum is attained.

Since

inf⁡{∑j=1∞yj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1∞yj⁢qjL=-xs}=infd⁡min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs}

and σ⁢(Y1)=supd⁡(σd⁢(Y1)), the equalities and inequalities (4.12) follow from proven equalities and inequalities (4.11). ∎

5. More Lemmas

We now let ℱ=∏α∈I*Gα be an arbitrary free product of nontrivial groups Gα, α∈I, |I|>1. Let H be a finitely generated factor-free subgroup of ℱ. As in Sect. 2, let Ψo⁢(H) denote an irreducible 𝒜-graph of H, where 𝒜=∪α∈IGα, with the base vertex o and let Ψ⁢(H) denote the core of Ψo⁢(H). Let I⁢(H) denote a subset of the index set I such that α∈I⁢(H) if and only if there is a secondary vertex u∈VS⁢Ψ⁢(H) of type α. Since H is finitely generated, it follows that I⁢(H) is finite.

We fix a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H1 of ℱ with positive reduced rank r¯⁢(H1)=-χ⁢(Ψ⁢(H1)) >0. We say that a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H2 of ℱ has property (B), resp. property (Bd), where d≥3 is an integer, relative to H1 if the core graph Ψ⁢(H2) of H2 has the original property (B), resp. property (Bd), in which the graphs Y1,Y2 are replaced with Ψ⁢(H1), Ψ⁢(H2), resp., i.e., r¯⁢(H2)=-χ⁢(Ψ⁢(H2))>0, deg⁡Ψ⁢(H2)≤d in case of property (Bd), and the map τ2:core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2))→Ψ⁢(H2) is surjective.

Lemma 5.1.

Suppose H2 is a finitely generated factor-free subgroup of F such that deg⁡Ψ⁢(H2)≤d, where d≥3 is an integer or d=∞, r¯⁢(H2)=-χ⁢(Ψ⁢(H2))>0, and the map τ2:core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2))→Ψ⁢(H2) is not surjective. Then there exists a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H4 of F with property (Bd) if d<∞ or with property (B) if d=∞ such that

r¯⁢(H1,H4)r¯⁢(H4)>r¯⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H2). (5.1)
Proof.

Recall that r¯⁢(H1,H2)=r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2))) and r¯⁢(Hi)=r¯⁢(Ψ⁢(Hi)), i=1,2. If r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2)))=0, then we may take H4=H1 and the inequality (5.1) holds. Assume that r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2)))>0 and that the map

τ2:core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2))→Ψ⁢(H2)

is not surjective. Consider the subgraph Γ:=τ2⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2))) of Ψ⁢(H2). It follows from the definitions and assumptions that r¯⁢(Γ)<r¯⁢(Ψ⁢(H2)) and

r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γ))=r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2)))>0,

whence r¯⁢(Γ)>0. It is also clear that core⁡(Γ)=Γ. Therefore,

r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γ))r¯⁢(Γ)>r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2)))r¯⁢(Ψ⁢(H2)). (5.2)

Let Γ1,…,Γk be connected components of the graph Γ. Since

r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γ))>0,

it follows that r¯⁢(Γ)>0. Note that the graph core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γ) consists of disjoint graphs core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj), j=1,…,k. In particular,

r¯⁢(Γ)=∑j=1kr¯⁢(Γj),r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γ))=∑j=1kr¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj)),

hence,

r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γ))r¯⁢(Γ)=∑j=1kr¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj))∑j=1kr¯⁢(Γj). (5.3)

Note that if r¯⁢(Γj)=0 then r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj))=0. Let Γj* be chosen so that r¯⁢(Γj*)>0 and the ratio

r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj*))r¯⁢(Γj*)

is maximal over those graphs Γj with r¯⁢(Γj)>0. It follows from r¯⁢(Γ)=∑j=1kr¯⁢(Γj)>0 that such j* does exist. It is not difficult to see that

∑j=1kr¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj))∑j=1kr¯⁢(Γj)≤r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj*))r¯⁢(Γj*).

This, together with (5.2) and (5.3), implies that

r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γj*))r¯⁢(Γj*)≥r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Γ))r¯⁢(Γ)>r¯⁢(core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2)))r¯⁢(Ψ⁢(H2)).

Hence, picking an arbitrary primary vertex v∈VP⁢Γj* in Γj* as a base point, and letting H4:=H⁢(Γj*,v), as in Lemma 2.2, we obtain a subgroup H4 with the desired inequality (5.1). ∎

Lemma 5.2.

The supremum sup⁡r¯⁢(H1,H3)r¯⁢(H3) over all finitely generated factor-free subgroups H3 of F with r¯⁢(H3)>0 and deg⁡Ψ⁢(H3)≤d, where d≥3 is an integer or d=∞, is equal to sup⁡r¯⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H2) over all finitely generated factor-free subgroups H2 of F that have property (Bd) (or property (B) if d=∞) relative to H1 and satisfy the condition I⁢(H2)⊆I⁢(H1). In particular,

σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)=σd⁢(Ψ⁢(H1))⁢r¯⁢(Ψ⁢(H1)) 𝑎𝑛𝑑 σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)=σ⁢(Ψ⁢(H1))⁢r¯⁢(Ψ⁢(H1)).
Proof.

This first claim follows from Lemma 5.1 and the observation that if the map τ2:core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1)×Ψ⁢(H2))→Ψ⁢(H2) is surjective then I⁢(H2)⊆I⁢(H1). The equalities follow from the first claim, definitions of numbers σd⁢(H1), σ⁢(H1), σd⁢(Ψ⁢(H1)), σ⁢(Ψ⁢(H1)), and Lemma 5.1. ∎

In view of Lemma 5.2, when investigating

sup⁡r¯⁢(H1,H3)r¯⁢(H3)

over all finitely generated factor-free subgroups H3 of ℱ with r¯⁢(H3)>0 and deg⁡Ψ⁢(H3)≤d, we may assume that the index set I is finite, i.e., I=I⁢(H1), say, I={1,…,m}, and so ℱ=G1*G2*…*Gm.

Furthermore, in order to be able to make use of results of Sects. 3–4, we consider ℱ as the following free product

ℱ2⁢(1)=G1*G⁢(2,m)

of two groups G1 and G⁢(2,m):=G2*…*Gm. Let gα∈Gα be some nontrivial element of Gα, α∈I={1,…,m}. For every aα∈Gα, consider the map

aα→(gα+1⁢…⁢gm⁢g1⁢…⁢gα)-1⁢aα⁢gα+1⁢…⁢gm⁢g1⁢…⁢gα, (5.4)

where gα+1⁢…⁢gm⁢g1⁢…⁢gα is a cyclic permutation of the word g1⁢g2⁢…⁢gm.

Recall that a subgroup K of a group G is called antinormal if, for every g∈G, g⁢K⁢g-1∩K≠{1} implies g∈K.

Lemma 5.3.

Let |I|=m≥3 and let H1 be a finitely generated factor-free subgroup of F. Then the map (5.4) extends to monomorphisms

μ:ℱ→ℱ,μ2:ℱ→ℱ2⁢(1)

that have the following properties.

(a) A word U∈F with |U|>1 is cyclically reduced if and only if μ⁢(U) is cyclically reduced.

(b) The subgroups μ2⁢(F), μ⁢(F) are antinormal in F2⁢(1), F, resp..

(c) μ2⁢(H1) is a factor-free subgroup of F2⁢(1) and μ⁢(H1) is factor-free in F. Furthermore, deg⁡Ψ⁢(H1)=deg⁡Ψ⁢(μ2⁢(H1)).

(d) If K1,K2 are finitely generated factor-free subgroups of F, then r¯⁢(K1,K2)=r¯⁢(μ2⁢(K1),μ2⁢(K2)).

(e) The supremum sup⁡r¯⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H2) over all finitely generated factor-free subgroups H2 of F such that r¯⁢(H2)>0 and deg⁡Ψ⁢(H2)≤d, where d≥3 is an integer, does not exceed sup⁡r¯⁢(μ2⁢(H1),K2)r¯⁢(K2) over all finitely generated factor-free subgroups K2 of F2⁢(1) with property (Bd) relative to μ2⁢(H1). In particular, σd⁢(H1)≤σd⁢(μ2⁢(H1)) and σ⁢(H1)≤σ⁢(μ2⁢(H1)).

Proof.

It is clear that the map (5.4) extends to homomorphisms

μ:ℱ→ℱ,μ2:ℱ→ℱ2⁢(1).

Note that if a1∈Gα1 and a2∈Gα2 are nontrivial elements and α1≠α2, then μ⁢(a1)⁢μ⁢(a2) is a cyclically reduced word. This remark implies that the kernels of the maps μ,μ2 are trivial, whence μ,μ2 are monomorphisms.

(a) It follows from the foregoing remark that a word U∈ℱ with |U|>1 is cyclically reduced if and only if μ⁢(U) is cyclically reduced.

(b) Let U1,U2∈ℱ be reduced words and W⁢μ⁢(U1)⁢W-1=μ⁢(U2) in ℱ. Using induction on |U1|+|U2|, we will prove that W∈μ⁢(ℱ). Suppose U1 is not cyclically reduced and U1≡a1⁢U3⁢a2, where a1,a2∈Gα∖{1} are letters of U1. Then we can replace U1 with U1′:=U3⁢a3, where a3∈Gα, a3=a2⁢a1 in Gα if a3≠1 or with U1′:=U3 if a3=1, and we replace W with W′:=W⁢μ2⁢(a1). This way we obtain an equality

W′⁢μ⁢(U1′)⁢(W′)-1⁢=0⁢μ⁢(U2)

in ℱ in which |U1′|+|U2|<|U1|+|U2|. Hence, it follows from the induction hypothesis that W∈μ⁢(ℱ), as required. If U2 is not cyclically reduced, then, analogously to what we did above for U1, we can decrease the sum |U1|+|U2| and use the induction hypothesis.

Thus we may assume that both words U1,U2 are cyclically reduced. By part (a), the words μ⁢(U1), μ⁢(U2) are also cyclically reduced. Observe that if W⁢V1⁢W-1=V2 in ℱ, where V1,V2 are cyclically reduced and W is reduced, then V2 is a cyclic permutation of V1. More specifically, there is a factorization V1≡V11⁢V12 and an integer k such that if k≥0 then W≡V12⁢V1k and if k≤0 then W≡V11-1⁢V1k. In either case, V2≡V12⁢V11. Applying this observation to the equality

W⁢μ⁢(U1)⁢W-1⁢=0⁢μ⁢(U2)

in ℱ, we can see from (5.4), when m≥3, that a cyclic permutation of μ⁢(U1) equal to μ⁢(U2) must have the form μ⁢(U¯1), where U¯1 is a cyclic permutation of U1. For similar reasons, W≡μ⁢(V) for some V∈ℱ and part (b) is proven for the subgroup μ⁢(ℱ). It now follows that μ2⁢(ℱ) is also antinormal in ℱ2⁢(1).

(c) Arguing on the contrary, suppose H is a factor-free subgroup of ℱ and one of μ⁢(H), μ2⁢(H) is not factor-free in ℱ, ℱ2⁢(1), resp. Then it follows from the definitions that μ2⁢(H) is not factor-free in ℱ2⁢(1). Hence, there is a reduced word U such that U is not conjugate in ℱ to a word of length ≤1 and

μ⁢(U)⁢=0⁢W⁢V⁢W-1 (5.5)

in ℱ, where W is either empty or reduced and V is either a letter of G1∖{1} or V is a reduced word with no letters of G1. Thus, V is reduced and either V∈G1 or V∈G⁢(2,m).

Assume that the word U in (5.5) is not cyclically reduced. Then U≡a1⁢U1⁢a2, where a1,a2∈Gα∖{1} are letters of U. If a1⁢a2=a3 in Gα and a3∈Gα∖{1}, then the word U′≡U1⁢a3, similarly to U, is not conjugate to ℱ to a word of length ≤1 and μ⁢(U′), being conjugate to μ⁢(U) in ℱ, has a representation of the form (5.5), so U can be replaced with U′. If a1⁢a2=1 in Gα, then the word U1 can be taken as U. Hence, by induction on |U|, we may assume that U is cyclically reduced.

If the word W⁢V⁢W-1 in (5.5) is not reduced, then there are words W′, V′ such that

μ⁢(U)⁢=0⁢W′⁢V′⁢(W′)-1,

W′, V′ have the foregoing properties of W, V, resp., and 2⁢|W′|+|V′|<2⁢|W|+|V|. Indeed, if, say W≡W1⁢a1 and V≡a2⁢V1, where a1,a2∈Gα∖{1}, then we set W′:=W1 and V′ is a reduced word equal in ℱ to a1⁢a2⁢V1⁢a1-1. Note that W′, V′ have the foregoing properties of W, V, resp., and |W′|=|W|-1, |V′|≤|V|+1, whence 2⁢|W′|+|V′|<2⁢|W|+|V|. Thus, by induction on 2⁢|W|+|V|, we may assume that the word W⁢V⁢W-1 in (5.5) is reduced.

Since U is cyclically reduced and |U|>1, it follows from part (a) that μ⁢(U) is cyclically reduced. Hence, the word W is empty and μ⁢(U)≡V, where V is a single letter of G1∖{1} or V has no letters of G1. However, neither situation is possible by the definition (5.4). This contradiction completes the proof of the first statement of part (c).

Now we will prove the equality deg⁡Ψ⁢(H1)=deg⁡Ψ⁢(μ2⁢(H1)) of part (c). It follows from the definition (5.4) that the graph Ψ⁢(μ2⁢(H)) can be visualized as a graph obtained from Ψ⁢(H) by subdivision of edges of Ψ⁢(H) into paths in accordance with formula (5.4) and subsequent “mergers” of edges that have labels in G2∪…∪Gm. In particular, for every vertex v∈V⁢Ψ⁢(H) with deg⁡v>2 there will be a unique vertex u=u⁢(v)∈VS⁢Ψ⁢(μ2⁢(H)) of degree deg⁡u=deg⁡v and this map v→u⁢(v) is bijective on the sets of all vertices of Ψ⁢(H), Ψ⁢(μ2⁢(H)) of degree >2. Hence, the maximal degree of vertices of Ψ⁢(μ2⁢(H)) is equal to that of Ψ⁢(H), as claimed.

(d) By part (c), the subgroups μ2⁢(K1),μ2⁢(K2) of ℱ2⁢(1) are factor-free and the subgroups μ⁢(K1), μ⁢(K2) of ℱ are also factor-free. Let T⁢(μ2⁢(K1),μ2⁢(K2)) be a set of representatives of those double cosets μ2⁢(K1)⁢U⁢μ2⁢(K2) of ℱ2⁢(1), U∈ℱ2⁢(1), that have the property μ2⁢(K1)∩U⁢μ2⁢(K2)⁢U-1≠{1}. If T∈T⁢(μ2⁢(K1),μ2⁢(K2)), then it follows from the definition of T⁢(μ2⁢(K1),μ2⁢(K2)) that there are nontrivial Vi∈Ki, i=1,2, such that T⁢μ2⁢(V2)⁢T-1=μ2⁢(V1)≠1 in ℱ2⁢(1). By part (b), such an equality implies T∈μ2⁢(ℱ) (note μ2 could be replaced with μ). Now we can see that there is a set S⁢(K1,K2)⊆ℱ such that μ2⁢(S⁢(K1,K2))=T⁢(μ2⁢(K1),μ2⁢(K2)) and S⁢(K1,K2) is a set of representatives of those double cosets K1⁢S⁢K2 of ℱ, S∈ℱ, that have the property K1∩S⁢K2⁢S-1≠{1}. Therefore,

r¯⁢(K1,K2):=∑S∈S⁢(K1,K2)r¯⁢(K1∩S⁢K2⁢S-1)=r¯⁢(μ2⁢(K1),μ2⁢(K2)),

as desired.

(e) This follows from Lemma 5.2, parts (c)–(d) and definitions. ∎

6. Proofs of Theorems

For reader’s convenience, we restate Theorems 1.1–1.3 before proving them.

Theorem 1.1.

Suppose that F=G1*G2 is the free product of two nontrivial groups G1,G2 and H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of F. Then the following claims are true.

(a) For every integer d≥3, there exists a linear programming problem (LP-problem)

𝒫⁢(H1,d)=max⁡{c⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)∣A⁢(d)⁢x⁢(d)≤b⁢(d)} (1.8)

with integer coefficients whose solution is equal to -σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1).

(b) There is a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H2* of F, H2*=H2*⁢(H1), which corresponds to a vertex solution of the dual problem

𝒫*⁢(H1,d)=min⁡{b⁢(d)⊤⁢y⁢(d)∣A⁢(d)⊤⁢y⁢(d)=c⁢(d)⊤,y⁢(d)≥0}

of the primal LP-problem (1.8) of part (a) such that r¯⁢(H1,H2*)=σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2*). In particular, the WNd-coefficient σd⁢(H1) of H1 is rational. Furthermore, if Ψ⁢(H1), Ψ⁢(H2*) denote irreducible core graphs representing subgroups H1,H2*, resp., and |E⁢Ψ| is the number of oriented edges in a graph Ψ, then

|E⁢Ψ⁢(H2*)|<224⁢|E⁢Ψ⁢(H1)|+1+log2⁡log2⁡(2⁢d).

(c) There exists a linear semi-infinite programming problem (LSIP-problem) P⁢(H1)=sup⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} with finitely many variables in x and with countably many constraints in the system A⁢x≤b whose dual problem

𝒫*⁢(H1)=inf⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0}

has a solution equal to -σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1).

(d) Let the word problem for both groups G1,G2 be solvable and let an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H1) of H1 be given. Then the LP-problem (1.8) of part (a) can be effectively written down and the WNd-coefficient σd⁢(H1) for H1 can be computed. In addition, an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H2*) of the subgroup H2* of part (b) can be effectively constructed.

(e) Let both G1,G2 be finite, let d:=max⁡(|G1|,|G2|)≥3, and let an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H1) of H1 be given. Then the LP-problem (1.8) of part (a) coincides with the LSIP-problem P⁢(H1) of part (c) and the WN-coefficient σ⁢(H1) for H1 is rational and computable.

Proof of Theorem 1.1.

Assume that I={1,2}, ℱ2=G1*G2 and H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of ℱ2. As before, let Ψo⁢(H1) denote a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph of H1 and Ψ⁢(H1) denote the core of Ψo⁢(H1).

Denote Y1:=Ψ⁢(H1) and pick an integer d≥3. As in Sects. 3–4, consider a system of linear inequalities 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] and an LP-problem

max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]}. (6.1)

According to Theorem A and Lemma 4.2, the maximum of the LP-problem (6.1) is equal to -σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1), where

σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)=sup⁡r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×Y2))r¯⁢(Y2)

over all finite irreducible 𝒜-graphs Y2 with property (Bd) relative to Y1. By Lemma 5.2, σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)=σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1), as desired in part (a).

According to Lemma 4.2, the minimum of the dual problem (4.5) of (6.1) is attained at a vector ^⁢y⁢(d) which is a vertex of the feasible polyhedron

{y∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} (6.2)

of the LP-problem (4.5). By Lemma 4.1, there is a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph ^⁢Y2 with property (Bd) such that

𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(^⁢Y2))=^⁢y⁢(d) and r¯⁢(core⁡(Y1×^⁢Y2))=σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(^⁢Y2). (6.3)

Assume that ^⁢Y2 is not connected and that ^⁢Y3,^⁢Y4 are (nonempty) subgraphs of ^⁢Y2 so that there is no path in ^⁢Y2 from any vertex of ^⁢Y3 to a vertex of ^⁢Y4. Clearly, ^⁢Y3,^⁢Y4 are finite irreducible 𝒜-graphs with property (Bd). Invoking Lemma 4.1, denote ^⁢yj:=𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(^⁢Yj)), j=3,4. By Lemma 4.1, ^⁢y3,^⁢y4 are points in the feasible polyhedron (6.2) of (4.5). It is easy to see from the definitions and Lemma 4.1 that ^⁢y⁢(d)=λ3⁢^⁢y3+λ4⁢^⁢y4 with some positive rational numbers λ3,λ4 that satisfy λ3+λ4=1. This, however, is impossible when ^⁢y⁢(d) is a vertex. This contradiction proves that ^⁢Y2 is a connected graph. Hence, there is a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H2* of ℱ whose irreducible graph Ψo*⁢(H2*) is ^⁢Y2, as required.

Now we establish the upper bound

|E⁢^⁢Y2|<224⁢|E⁢Y1|+1+log2⁡(log2⁡2⁢d) (6.4)

on size of ^⁢Y2, where ^⁢Y2 is defined by equalities (6.3). Recall that it follows from Lemma 4.2 that

-σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1) =min⁡{∑j=1idyj⁢qjR∣y≥0,∑j=1idyj⁢qjL=-xs} (6.5)
=min⁡{b⊤⁢y∣A⊤⁢y=c⊤,y≥0} (6.6)
=max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b}=max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]}. (6.7)

It is convenient to switch back to the general LP notation as was introduced in Sect. 4 and reminded in (6.5)–(6.7). In particular, let A be an m×n matrix, i.e., m=id and n is the number of variables.

According to Theorem C, we may assume that the minimum of the dual LP-problem (6.5) is attained at a vertex ^⁢y⁢(d), ^⁢y⁢(d)≥0, of the feasible polyhedron {y∣y≥0,∑j=1myj⁢qjL=-xs} of the LP-problem (6.5) whose positive components ^⁢yi⁢(d) correspond to linearly independent left-hand sides qiL of the inequalities qi, i=1,…,m, of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]. Reordering the inequalities of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] if necessary, we may assume that ^⁢y1⁢(d),…,^⁢yr⁢(d) are positive, q1L,…,qrL are linearly independent and that ^⁢yr+1⁢(d)=…=^⁢ym⁢(d)=0.

Recall that A⁢x≤b is the matrix form of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] and A has size m×n. Let Ar,n denote the submatrix of A that consists of the first r rows of A, hence, ^⁢y1⁢(d),…,^⁢yr⁢(d) correspond to linearly independent rows of Ar,n. Let Ar×r denote a submatrix of Ar,n of size r×r with det⁡Ar×r≠0 and let y¯⁢(d)=(^⁢y1⁢(d),…,^⁢yr⁢(d))⊤ be a truncated version of ^⁢y⁢(d). Then

Ar×r⊤⁢y¯⁢(d)=(c1,…,cr)⊤=c¯⊤.

Since ∑i=1m^⁢yi⁢(d)⁢qiL=-xs, it follows that cj=0 if cj corresponds to the column of a variable xB in Ar,n and cj=-1 if cj corresponds to the column of xs. Since ^⁢y⁢(d)≠0, we conclude that c¯⊤≠0, hence, one of cj in c¯⊤ is -1 and all other entries of c¯⊤ are equal to 0. Since every entry of Ar×r is 0 or ±k′ or -(k-2), where 1≤k′≤d, 2≤k≤d, and every row of Ar×r contains at most d+1 nonzero entries which are sums of coefficients of variables in an inequality (3.4)–(3.5), it follows that the standard Euclidian norm of any row of Ar×r is at most (d2+(d-2)2)1/2<d2 as d≥3. Hence, by Hadamard’s inequality, we obtain

|det⁡Ar×r|<d2⁢r. (6.8)

Invoking the Cramer’s rule, we further have that

^⁢yi⁢(d)=det⁡Ar×r,i⊤⁢(c¯⊤)det⁡Ar×r, (6.9)

where Ar×r,i⊤⁢(c¯⊤) is the matrix obtained from Ar×r by replacing the ith column with c¯⊤, i=1,…,r. Similarly to Ar×r, see (6.8), we obtain that

|det⁡Ar×r,i⁢(c¯⊤)|<d2⁢r-2 (6.10)

for ∥c¯⊤∥=1.

In view of (6.8)–(6.10), we can see that a common denominator L>0 of positive rational numbers ^⁢y1⁢(d),…,^⁢yr⁢(d) satisfies L<d2⁢r and that positive integers L⁢^⁢y1⁢(d),…,L⁢^⁢yr⁢(d) are less than d2⁢r-2.

It follows from the definition of the function 𝗌𝗈𝗅d, see also Lemma 4.1, that if ^⁢y⁢(d)=𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(^⁢Q) then

|^⁢Q|<r⁢d2⁢r-2, (6.11)

where |Q| is the cardinality of a combination with repetitions Q⊑𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] defined so that every element q∈Q is counted as many times as it occurs in Q.

Recall that 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(^⁢Y2)=^⁢Q. It follows from the definition of the function 𝗂𝗇𝗊, see also Lemma 3.3, that |VS⁢^⁢Y2|=|^⁢Q| and, therefore, by (6.11), we get

|E⁢^⁢Y2|≤2⁢d⁢|VS⁢^⁢Y2|=2⁢d⁢|^⁢Q|<2⁢d⁢r⁢d2⁢r-2<2⁢r⁢d2⁢r. (6.12)

Note that r does not exceed the number n of variables xB,xs of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]. Since every index B of xB is a nonempty subset of VP⁢Y1, it follows that

r≤n≤(2|VP⁢Y1|-1)+1=24⁢|E⁢Y1| (6.13)

for |VP⁢Y1|=4⁢|E⁢Y1| as every primary vertex of Y1 has degree 2.

Finally, we obtain from (6.12)–(6.13) that

|E⁢^⁢Y2| <2⁢r⁢d2⁢r=24⁢|E⁢Y1|+1⁢d24⁢|E⁢Y1|+1<24⁢|E⁢Y1|+1+log2⁡d⋅24⁢|E⁢Y1|+1
<2(log2⁡d+1)⋅24⁢|E⁢Y1|+1≤2log2⁡(2⁢d)⋅24⁢|E⁢Y1|+1
≤224⁢|E⁢Y1|+1+log2⁡log2⁡(2⁢d).

This completes the proof of part (b) of Theorem 1.1.

To prove part (c), we note that it follows from Lemmas 4.2 and 5.2 that the dual problem (4.4) of the LSIP-problem sup⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]}, where Y1=Ψ⁢(H1), has the infimum equal to -σ⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)=-σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1). This proves part (c).

Now we turn to parts (d)–(e) of Theorem 1.1. First we discuss how to effectively write down inequalities of the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1], d=3,4,…. Recall that every inequality of 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1] is written in the form (3.4)–(3.5) and there are finitely many subsets A⊆S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) that are indices of k variables ±xA in the left-hand sides of inequalities (3.4)–(3.5), where 2≤k=|T|≤d. The coefficient of xs is the integer -(k-2) and the right-hand side of (3.4)–(3.5) is an integer -N⁢(ΩT)α, where

0≤N⁢(ΩT)α≤(d-2)⁢|VP⁢Y1|,

see (3.3). This information is sufficient to conclude that the set of inequalities in the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] is finite. However, this information is not sufficient to effectively write down inequalities of 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] because the set of available sets T is infinite whenever G1∪G2 is infinite.

To explicitly write down the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1], we assume that the word problem for both groups G1,G2 is solvable and we will look more closely into construction of inequalities (3.4)–(3.5).

Recall that inequalities (3.4)–(3.5) are defined in Sect. 3 by using an α-admissible function ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), where T∈S2⁢(Gα) and α∈I={1,2}.

We also recall that ∼ΩT denotes an equivalence relation on the set of all pairs (a,u), where a∈T and u∈ΩT⁢(a), see Sect. 3. Making use of the equivalence relation ∼ΩT, we define a relation ≈ on the set T so that a≈b if and only if there are u∈ΩT⁢(a), v∈ΩT⁢(b) such that (a,u)∼ΩT(b,v). Note that this relation ≈ is reflexive and symmetric. The transitive closure of the relation ≈ is an equivalence relation on T which we denote by ≈ΩT. The equivalence class of a∈T is denoted [a]≈ΩT. It follows from the definition of [a]≈ΩT and from the property of being α-admissible for ΩT that, for every b1∈[a]≈ΩT, there is an element b2∈[a]≈ΩT such that b2≠b1 and there are edges e1,e2∈E⁢Y1 such that (e1)+=(e2)+∈VS⁢Y1, the vertex (e1)+ has type α, (ei)-∈ΩT⁢(bi), i=1,2, and

b1⁢b2-1=φ⁢(e1)⁢φ⁢(e2)-1 (6.14)

in Gα. Note that if we connect every two such elements b1,b2∈[a]≈ΩT by an edge, then the graph Γ⁢(ΩT), whose vertex set is T, will have connected components whose vertex sets are equivalence classes [a]≈ΩT of T. This connectedness of subgraphs of Γ⁢(ΩT) on vertex sets [a]≈ΩT obviously implies the following claim.

Lemma 6.1.

The equations (6.14) can be used to determine all elements of the equivalence class [a]≈ΩT if only one element in [a]≈ΩT is known.

Proof.

This easily follows from definitions. ∎

Let C⁢(α,d) be a subset of Gα of cardinality |C⁢(α,d)|=d2+d, α=1,2, where d≥3 is a fixed integer. In the arguments below, this set C⁢(α,d) will be held fixed. Note that if |Gα|<d2+d, so it is not possible to choose d2+d distinct elements in Gα, then all inequalities (3.4) if α=1 or (⁢3.5⁢) if α=2 for k≤d, where as before k=|T|, can be written down effectively for the following reasons: The sets S2⁢(Gα) and {ΩT∣ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1),T∈S2⁢(Gα)} are finite, can be written down explicitly, and it is possible to verify whether given function ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) is α-admissible. Clearly, the same conclusion holds if both G1,G2 are finite but in the arguments below we will only need the inequality |C⁢(α,d)|=d2+d, hence we can just assume that |Gα|≥d2+d.

Consider a subset C⊂C⁢(α,d), where 1≤|C|≤k≤d and a set of indeterminates Z={z1,…,zk-|C|}. Note |C∪Z|=k. Consider a function

ΩC∪Z:C∪Z→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1). (6.15)

Similarly to the relation ∼ΩT defined in Sect. 3, we consider a relation ∼ΩC∪Z on the set of all pairs (a,u), where a∈C∪Z and u∈ΩC∪Z⁢(a), defined as follows. Two pairs (a,u) and (b,v) are related by ∼ΩC∪Z if and only if either (a,u)=(b,v) or, otherwise, there exist edges e,f∈E⁢Y1 such that e-=u, f-=v and the secondary vertex e+=f+ has type α.

We also consider an analogue ≈Z of the relation ≈ defined above so that a≈Zb, where a,b∈C∪Z, if and only if there are u∈ΩC∪Z⁢(a), v∈ΩC∪Z⁢(b) such that (a,u)∼ΩC∪Z(b,v). As before, the relation ≈Z is reflexive and symmetric. By taking the transitive closure of the relation ≈Z we obtain an equivalence relation on the set C∪Z which is denoted by ≈ΩC∪Z.

We will say that a function ΩC∪Z, as in (6.15), is unacceptable if there is an equivalence class [(a,u)]∼ΩC∪Z of ∼ΩC∪Z with a single element in it or there is an equivalence class [a]≈ΩC∪Z of the relation ≈ΩC∪Z that contains no elements of C. Note that, when given a function ΩC∪Z as in (6.15), we can algorithmically check whether or not ΩC∪Z is unacceptable.

If now the function ΩC∪Z is not found to be unacceptable, then we attempt to construct a function ζ:Z→Gα by using the following algorithm.

First, we set ζ0⁢(c)=c if c∈C and let C0:=C, Z0:=∅. Consider the set of all triples (a,u,ℓ), where a∈C∪Z, u∈ΩC∪Z⁢(a), 1≤ℓ≤d+1, and do the following. By induction on i≥0, assume that the sets Ci⊆Gα, Zi⊆Z are constructed and a bijective function ζi:C0∪Zi→Ci is defined so that the restriction of ζi on C0 is ζ0. For every unordered pair {(a,u,ℓ),(b,v,ℓ)} of distinct triples with a fixed ℓ (first we use ℓ=1, then ℓ=2 and so on up to ℓ=d+1), we check whether there are edges e,f∈E⁢Y1 such that e-=u, f-=v, e+=f+, and e+=f+∈VS⁢Y1 has type α. If there are no such edges, then we pass on to the next pair {(a,u,ℓ),(b,v,ℓ)}. If there are such edges e,f, then we consider three Cases 1–3 below, perform the described actions and pass on to the next pair. We remark that these actions can be algorithmically implemented as follows from the solvability of the word problem for G1,G2 and the availability of the graph Y1=Ψ⁢(H1).

Case 1.  If both a,b∈C∪Zi, then we check whether the equality

ζi⁢(a)⁢ζi⁢(b)-1=φ⁢(e)⁢φ⁢(f)-1

holds in Gα. If this equality is false, then we conclude that the function ΩC∪Z is unacceptable and stop. Otherwise, we set

Zi+1:=Zi,Ci+1:=Ci,ζi+1:=ζi.

Case 2.  Suppose that exactly one of a,b is in C∪Zi, say b∈C∪Zi. Then it is clear that a∈Z∖Zi and we can uniquely determine an element η⁢(a) by solving the equation η⁢(a)⁢ζi⁢(b)-1=φ⁢(e)⁢φ⁢(f)-1. If η⁢(a)∈Ci, then we conclude that the function ΩC∪Z is unacceptable and stop. Otherwise, we set

Zi+1:=Zi∪{a},Ci+1:=Ci∪{η⁢(a)}

and define a function ζi+1 on the set C∪Zi+1 so that ζi+1⁢(a):=η⁢(a) and the restriction of ζi+1 on C∪Zi is ζi.

Case 3.  If both a,b∉C∪Zi, then we set

Zi+1:=Zi,Ci+1:=Ci,ζi+1:=ζi.

Cases 1–3 are complete.

Since every equivalence class [a]≈ΩC∪Z contains an element of C, it follows from the definitions that while this algorithm runs over all pairs for a fixed ℓ′=1,…,d, one of the following three Cases (C1)–(C3) will occur.

  1. (C1)

    For some i, |Zi+1|=|Zi|+1.

  2. (C2)

    The set ΩC∪Z is found to be unacceptable.

  3. (C3)

    For the index i, corresponding to the last pair {(a,u,ℓ′),(b,v,ℓ′)} for parameter ℓ equal to ℓ′, one has Zi=Z.

Since |Z|≤d-1, we can see that it is not possible for Case (C1) to occur for all ℓ′=1,…,d. Hence, running this algorithm consecutively for ℓ′=1,…,d, results either in conclusion that the function ΩC∪Z is unacceptable or in construction of a bijective function

ζ=ζi:C∪Z→Ci⊆Gα,

where Zi=Z, in which case we say that the function ΩC∪Z is acceptable. Furthermore, setting T:=ζ⁢(C∪Z) and ΩT⁢(ζ⁢(a)):=ΩC∪Z⁢(a) for every a∈C∪Z, we obtain an α-admissible function ΩT on the set T⊆Gα.

Observe that the set of all such functions ΩC∪Z:C∪Z→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), where C⊆C⁢(α,d) and Z={z1,…,zk-|C|}, see (6.15), is finite (recall the set C⁢(α,d) is fixed) and that all such functions can be written down explicitly. Moreover, using the foregoing algorithm, we can verify whether a function ΩC∪Z is acceptable and, when doing so, construct a unique function ζ:C∪Z→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), where T:=ζ⁢(C∪Z), so that ΩT⁢(ζ⁢(a)):=ΩC∪Z⁢(a) for every a∈C∪Z and ζ⁢(c)=c if c∈C. Therefore, in order to establish that inequalities (3.4)–(3.5) can be effectively written down, it remains to prove the following.

Lemma 6.2.

For every α-admissible function ΩT′:T′→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1), where T′⊂Gα and 2≤|T′|=k≤d, there exists an acceptable function

ΩC∪Z:C∪Z→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1),

where C⊂C⁢(α,d) and Z={z1,…,zk-|C|}, such that if T:=ζ⁢(C∪Z) and if ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) is the α-admissible function, defined by ΩT⁢(ζ⁢(a)):=ΩC∪Z⁢(a) for every a∈C∪Z and ζ⁢(c)=c for c∈C, then the two inequalities (3.4), that correspond to ΩT′ and to ΩT if α=1, or the two inequalities (3.5), that correspond to ΩT′ and to ΩT if α=2, are identical.

To prove Lemma 6.2, we first establish an auxiliary lemma.

Lemma 6.3.

Suppose ΩT′:T′→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) is an α-admissible function, where 2≤|T′|≤d, and T′=E1∪…∪Er is a partition of T′ into equivalence classes [a]≈ΩT′ of the equivalence relation ≈ΩT′. Then there are elements h1,…,hr∈Gα such that the set T:=E1⁢h1∪…∪Er⁢hr has cardinality |T|=|T′| and every set Ei⁢hi, i=1,…,r, contains an element from the set C⁢(α,d).

Proof.

By induction on i, where 1≤i≤r, we will prove the existence of elements h1,…,hi∈Gα with the property that the set E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi has cardinality ∑j=1i|Ej⁢hj| and every set Ej⁢hj, j=1,…,i, contains an element from C⁢(α,d).

If i=1, then we set h1:=b-1⁢c, where b∈E1 and c∈C⁢(α,d).

Making the induction hypothesis, assume that there are elements h1,…,hi∈Gα with the desired properties.

To make the induction step from i to i+1, denote

Ci⁢(α,d):=C⁢(α,d)∩(E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi)

and let b∈Ei+1. For an element c∈C⁢(α,d)∖Ci⁢(α,d), we consider the set Rc:=Ei+1⁢b-1⁢c. Clearly, Rc contains an element from C⁢(α,d) and if Rc is disjoint from E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi, then we can set hi+1:=b-1⁢c. Therefore, we may assume that Rc contains an element from E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi for every c∈C⁢(α,d)∖Ci⁢(α,d).

Suppose that elements in E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi are indexed by integers from 1 to |E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi| and elements in Rc=Ei+1⁢b-1⁢c, where b and c are chosen as above, are indexed by integers from 1 to |Ei+1| so that, for every e∈Ei+1, the index of e⁢b-1⁢c∈Rc is equal to that of e∈Ei+1. Thus, we wish to keep indices stable when multiplying Ei+1 by b-1⁢c.

Making use of these indices, we fix an element b∈Ei+1 and, for every c∈C⁢(α,d)∖Ci⁢(α,d), we consider the pair (jR⁢(c),jE⁢(c)) of indices jR⁢(c),jE⁢(c) in Rc=Ei+1⁢b-1⁢c and in E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi, resp., of an element of the intersection Rc∩(E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi) which is not empty as was assumed above.

Suppose that (jR⁢(c1),jE⁢(c1))=(jR⁢(c2),jE⁢(c2)). Then it follows from the definitions that if e1,e2∈Ei+1 are such that

e1⁢b-1⁢c1∈Rc1∩(E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi) and e2⁢b-1⁢c2∈Rc2∩(E1⁢h1∪…∪Ei⁢hi),

then e1=e2 and e1⁢b-1⁢c1=e2⁢b-1⁢c2 in Gα. These equalities imply that c1=c2. Therefore, for distinct elements c1,c2∈C⁢(α,d)∖Ci⁢(α,d), the pairs (jR⁢(c1),jE⁢(c1)), (jR⁢(c2),jE⁢(c2)) are also distinct. However, the number of elements c in C⁢(α,d)∖Ci⁢(α,d) is

|C⁢(α,d)|-|Ci⁢(α,d)|≥(d2+d)-d=d2

and the number of all such pairs (jR⁢(c),jE⁢(c)) is less than d2. This contradiction completes the induction step and Lemma 6.3 is proved. ∎

Proof of Lemma 6.2.

Utilizing the notation of Lemma 6.3, we let T′=E1∪…∪Er and let h1,…,hr∈Gα be elements such that the set T:=E1⁢h1∪…∪Er⁢hr has cardinality |T|=|T′|=k and every set Ei⁢hi, i=1,…,r, contains an element from C⁢(α,d). Define a function ^⁢Ω:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) so that if a∈Ei, i=1,…,r, then ^⁢Ω⁢(a⁢hi):=ΩT′⁢(a). Define C:=C⁢(α,d)∩T and let C={c1,…,c|C|}. Introducing more notation, denote T={c1,…,c|C|,b1,…,bk-|C|} and Z={z1,…,zk-|C|}. Define a function ΩC∪Z→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) by setting ΩC∪Z⁢(ci):=^⁢Ω⁢(ci) and ΩC∪Z⁢(zj):=^⁢Ω⁢(bj) for all i,j. In view of Lemma 6.1, it is not difficult to see that the function ΩC∪Z is acceptable, ζ⁢(C∪Z)=T, and if ΩT:T→S1⁢(VP⁢Y1) is the function defined by ΩT⁢(ζ⁢(a)):=ΩC∪Z⁢(a) for every a∈C∪Z, where ζ⁢(c)=c for c∈C, then the following hold: ΩT is an α-admissible function, ΩT=^⁢Ω, and the inequalities (3.4) if α=1 or the inequalities (3.5) if α=2, corresponding to ΩT′ and to ΩT, are identical. Lemma 6.2 is proved. ∎

To finish the proof of part (d) of Theorem 1.1, we remark that, by Lemma 6.2, the LP-problem max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]} can be effectively written down. Solving this LP-problem we obtain, by Lemma 4.2, the number -σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1) which is equal to -σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1) by Lemma 5.2. Since the number r¯⁢(Y1)=r¯⁢(H1) is computable off the graph Y1, the coefficient σd⁢(Y1) is also computable.

Since the LP-problem max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]} can be effectively written down, its dual problem (6.5) can also be effectively constructed. Using the notation of the foregoing proof of parts (a)–(c), we observe that a vertex solution ^⁢y⁢(d) to (6.5) can be computed, see [25]. Hence, a combination with repetitions ^⁢Q such that 𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(^⁢Q)=^⁢y⁢(d) is also computable. Therefore, a graph ^⁢Y2=Ψ⁢(H2*) such that 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(^⁢Y2)=^⁢Q can be effectively constructed and the proof of part (d) is complete.

To show part (e), we note that if both groups G1,G2 are finite, then any irreducible finite 𝒜-graph Ψ has the property that deg⁡u≤max⁡{|G1|,|G2|} for every secondary vertex u∈VS⁢Ψ. Hence, letting d:=max⁡{|G1|,|G2|}, we obtain 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]=𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] and so, by Lemma 4.2, σ⁢(Y1)=σd⁢(Y1). Since the coefficient σd⁢(Y1) is rational and computable by part (d), the number σ⁢(H1)=σ⁢(Y1) is also rational and computable. Theorem 1.1 is proved. ∎

Theorem 1.2.

Suppose that F=G1*G2 is the free product of two nontrivial finite groups G1,G2 and H1 is a subgroup of F given by a finite generating set S of words over the alphabet A=G1∪G2. Then the following are true.

(a) In deterministic polynomial time of size of S, one can determine whether H1 is factor-free and noncyclic and, if so, one can construct an irreducible graph Ψo⁢(H1) of H1.

(b) If H1 is factor-free and noncylcic, then, in deterministic exponential time of size of S, one can write down and solve an LP-problem P=max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} whose solution is equal to -σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1). In particular, the W⁢N-coefficient σ⁢(H1) of H1 is computable in deterministic exponential time of size of S.

(c) If H1 is factor-free and noncylcic, then, in deterministic double exponential time of size of S, one can construct an irreducible core graph Ψ⁢(H2*) of H2*, where H2* is a finitely generated factor-free subgroup F such that r¯⁢(H1,H2*)=σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2*). In addition, if |E⁢Ψ| denotes the number of oriented edges of a graph Ψ, Ψ⁢(H1) is an irreducible core graph of H1, and d:=max⁡(|G1|,|G2|), then |E⁢Ψ⁢(H2*)|<224⁢|E⁢Ψ⁢(H1)|+1+log2⁡log2⁡(2⁢d).

Proof of Theorem 1.2.

Part (a) follows from Lemma 2.1.

To show part (b), we observe that, in the case when G1,G2 are finite, we can effectively write down the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1], where d=max⁡{|G1|,|G2|}, and this can be done in exponential time of size of Y1. Furthermore, by Lemma 2.1, the size of the graph Y1 is polynomial in size ∑S∈𝒮|S| of the generating set 𝒮. It follows from Theorem 1.1(e) that 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]=𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]. The size of the system 𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]=𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1] is exponential in size of Y1. Hence, the size of the primal LP-problem max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]} as well as the size of the dual problem (4.5) are exponential in size of Y1. By Theorem 1.1 and Lemma 5.2, an optimal solution to the dual problem (4.5) is equal to

-σd⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)=-σd⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1)=-σ⁢(Y1)⁢r¯⁢(Y1)=-σ⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H1).

It remains to mention that an LP-problem max⁡{c⁢x∣A⁢x≤b} can be solved in polynomial time of size of the problem, see [25], and that the reduced rank r¯⁢(Y1)=r¯⁢(H1) can be computed in polynomial time of size of Y1.

To prove part (c), we note that the size of the dual LP-problem (4.5), similarly to size of max⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨d⁡[Y1]}, is at most exponential in size of Y1 and that a vertex solution ^⁢y⁢(d) to (4.5) can be computed in polynomial time of size of the dual LP-problem (4.5), see [25]. Note that here and below we use the notation of the proof of part (b) of Theorem 1.1. Hence, both a vertex solution ^⁢y⁢(d) and a combination with repetitions ^⁢Q such that 𝗌𝗈𝗅d⁡(^⁢Q)=^⁢y⁢(d) can be computed in deterministic exponential time of size of Y1. In view of inequalities (6.11) and (6.13), we obtain that

|^⁢Q|<r⁢d2⁢r-2<24⁢|E⁢Y1|⁢d24⁢|E⁢Y1|+1=22O⁢(|E⁢Y1|).

Therefore, a desired graph ^⁢Y2=Ψ⁢(H2*) such that 𝗂𝗇𝗊⁡(^⁢Y2)=^⁢Q can be constructed from ^⁢Q (this construction is similar to the proof of Lemma 3.2) in deterministic double exponential time of size of Y1=Ψ⁢(H1).

The inequality

|E⁢Ψ⁢(H2*)|<224⁢|E⁢Ψ⁢(H1)|+1+log2⁡log2⁡(2⁢d),

where, as above, d=max⁡(|G1|,|G2|), follows from part (d) of Theorem 1.1. Theorem 1.2 is proved. ∎

Theorem 1.3.

Suppose that F=∏α∈I*Gα is the free product of nontrivial groups Gα, α∈I, and H1 is a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup of F. Then there are two disjoint finite subsets I1,I2 of I such that if ^⁢G1:=∏α∈I1*Gα, ^⁢G2:=∏α∈I2*Gα, and ^⁢F:=^⁢G1*^⁢G2, then there exists a finitely generated factor-free subgroup ^⁢H1 of ^⁢F with the following properties.

(a) r¯⁢(^⁢H1)=r¯⁢(H1), σd⁢(^⁢H1)≥σd⁢(H1) for every d≥3, and σ⁢(^⁢H1)≥σ⁢(H1). In particular, if the conjecture (1.5) fails for H1 then the conjecture (1.5) also fails for ^⁢H1.

(b) If the word problem for all groups Gα, α∈I1∪I2, is solvable and a finite irreducible graph of H1 is given, then the LP-problem P⁢(^⁢H1,d) for ^⁢H1 of part (a) of Theorems 1.1 can be effectively written down and the WNd-coefficient σd⁢(^⁢H1) for ^⁢H1 can be computed.

(c) Let groups Gα, where α∈I1∪I2, be finite, let H1 be effectively given either by a finite irreducible graph or by a finite generating set, and let

d′:=max⁡{|I1∪I2|,max⁡{|Gα|:α∈I1∪I2}}.

Then σd′⁢(^⁢H1)≥σ⁢(H1) and there is an algorithm that decides whether the conjecture (1.5) holds for H1.

Proof of Theorem 1.3.

(a) We assume that the subgroup H1 is given by an irreducible 𝒜-graph Ψ⁢(H1) with core⁡(Ψ⁢(H1))=Ψ⁢(H1). Note that it is also possible to assume that H1 is defined by a finite generating elements 𝒮 whose elements are words over 𝒜. In the latter case, we would apply Lemma 2.1 which, when given a finite generating set of a subgroup H of ℱ, verifies that H is a factor-free subgroup of ℱ and, if so, constructs an irreducible 𝒜-graph of H.

Making use of the graph Y1:=Ψ⁢(H1) of H1, we switch from the original index set I to its finite subset I⁢(H1) and rename it by {1,…,m}. Here and below we use the notation introduced in Sect. 5. Without loss of generality, we may assume that m≥3, otherwise we may set ^⁢H1:=H1. Consider an embedding μ2:ℱ→ℱ2⁢(1) defined by means of the map (5.4), where ℱ2⁢(1)=G1*G⁢(2,m) and G⁢(2,m)=G2*…*Gm. Denote ^⁢H1:=μ2⁢(H1). Then r¯⁢(^⁢H1)=r¯⁢(H1) and, by Lemma 5.3(e), σd⁢(H1)≤σd⁢(^⁢H1) for every d≥3. Consequently, σ⁢(H1)≤σ⁢(^⁢H1) as well. This proves part (a).

(b) Assume that the word problem is solvable in groups Gα, α∈I⁢(H1). Then the word problem is also solvable in factors G1,G⁢(2,m) of the free product ℱ2⁢(1)=G1*G⁢(2,m). Furthermore, using the graph Y1 of H1 and the map (5.4), we can effectively construct a finite irreducible 𝒜-graph Ψ⁢(^⁢H1) with core⁡(Ψ⁢(^⁢H1))=Ψ⁢(^⁢H1). By Theorem 1.1(d), the LP-problem 𝒫⁢(^⁢H1,d)=𝒫⁢(Ψ⁢(^⁢H1),d), associated with ^⁢H1, can be effectively constructed and the coefficient σd⁢(^⁢H1) can be computed, as claimed in part (b).

(c) We will continue to use the notation introduced above. Suppose that all factors Gα, where α∈I⁢(H1)={1,…,m}, are finite and H1 is effectively given by its irreducible 𝒜-graph Y1:=Ψ⁢(H1) with core⁡(Y1)=Y1 (or by a finite generating set; Lemma 2.1 reduces the latter case to the former one). By Lemma 5.2, when computing the number σ⁢(H1)=sup⁡r¯⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2), we may assume that the subgroup H2 has property (B) and satisfies the condition I⁢(H2)⊆I⁢(H1). The latter condition implies that the degree of any primary vertex of Y2:=Ψ⁢(H2) does not exceed |I⁢(H1)|. On the other hand, the degree of every secondary vertex of Y2 does not exceed max⁡{|Gα|:α∈I⁢(H1)}. Hence, the degree deg⁡v of every vertex v of Y2 satisfies

deg⁡v≤d′:=max⁡{|I⁢(H1)|,max⁡{|Gα|:α∈I⁢(H1)}}. (6.16)

Thus, by Lemma 5.2, we may conclude that

σ⁢(H1)=σd′⁢(H1)=sup⁡r¯⁢(H1,H2)r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2),

where the supremum is taken over all subgroups H2 with property (Bd), where d=d′. Applying Lemma 5.3(e) to H1, we obtain σ⁢(H1)=σd′⁢(H1)≤σd′⁢(^⁢H1). Recall that an irreducible graph Ψ⁢(^⁢H1) of ^⁢H1=μ2⁢(H1) can be effectively constructed from Y1 (for details see the proof of Lemma 5.3(c)) and the word problem is solvable for factors of the free product ℱ2⁢(1)=G1*G⁢(2,m). Invoking Theorem 1.1(d), we see that the LP-problem 𝒫⁢(^⁢H1,d′)=𝒫⁢(Ψ⁢(^⁢H1),d′) can be written down and hence the coefficient σd′⁢(^⁢H1) can be computed, as desired. The proof of Theorem 1.3 is complete. ∎

In conclusion, we mention that it is not clear whether there is a duality gap between the LSIP-problem sup⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]}, introduced in Sect. 4, and its dual problem (4.4) and it would be of interest to find this out. Another natural problem is to find an algorithm that solves the dual problem (4.4) of the LSIP-problem sup⁡{-xs∣𝖲𝖫𝖨⁡[Y1]} and thereby effectively computes the WN-coefficient σ⁢(Ψ⁢(H1))=σ⁢(H1) for a finitely generated factor-free subgroup H1 of the free product of two groups (and, perhaps, more than two groups) which are not necessarily finite. It would also be interesting to find an algorithm that computes the Hanna Neumann coefficient σ¯⁢(H1) for a finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroup H1 of the free product ℱ of two finite groups which is defined as σ¯⁢(H1):=sup⁡r¯⁢(H1∩H2)r¯⁢(H1)⁢r¯⁢(H2) over all finitely generated factor-free noncyclic subgroups H2 of ℱ.
